questions.text: A child presented with pain in the forearm following a trauma. The radiograph of the forearm reveal the findings as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Galeazzi fracture

 

Explanation:

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • Fracture of distal third of radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and triangular fibrocartilage complex
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.

 

 

Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles’s fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women, as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. Most Colles fractures can be successfully treated nonoperatively, and cast (hand-shaking cast) is applied on opposite forces to displacement. Complications include finger stiffness (most common), malunion (2nd most common) leading to dinner fork deformity. Colles’s fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.

 

Dinner fork deformity

 

 

Reduction and application of Hand-shaking cast

 

Option B. Smith’s fracture. A Smith fracture is a break to the end of the radius. The end part of the bone, which forms part of the wrist joint, is displaced or angled in the direction of the palm of the hand. Often, this injury occurs by a fall to the back of a flexed wrist but can occur in any fall to an outstretched hand. Smith fracture is treated by close reduction and immobilization in long arm (above elbow) cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension (dorsiflexion).

 

 

Option C. Monteggia fracture. Fractures between the proximal third of the ulna and the base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint. The clue to successful treatment is to restore the length of the fractured ulna; only then can the dislocated joint be fully reduced and remain stable. In adults, treatment is reduction and fixation. In children, treatment is reduction and cast application. Posterior interosseous nerve has been most commonly injured nerve in association with Monteggia fracture dislocation because it takes a turn around radial head and is injured with its dislocation. This causes paralysis of thumb and finger extensors.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question reveals a Galeazzi fracture of the forearm.

choices.text: Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position
Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done using the instrument given in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated if platelet count <40,000

 

The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, and platelet transfusion can be performed if clinically warranted prior to the procedure, commonly performed if platelet counts are below 20,000 cells/microliter.

 

 

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

 

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin, suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections, or granulomatous diseases

 

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy:

 

  • Severe hemophilia
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Severe bleeding disorders

 

Procedure for bone marrow biopsy:

 

Prone or lateral position is chosen for the procedure. Posterior superior iliac spine is identified. After disinfection and local anesthesia, the patient is asked to inhale slowly through the nose and exhale slowly through the mouth to relieve anxiety. The needle is inserted and rotated on its axis.

 

On reaching the desired depth, the stylet is removed and needle is advanced. The needle is rotated in the opposite direction to loosen the specimen. It is then withdrawn using the same rotational movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breath holding is required: This is true for minimizing patient movement during the procedure.

 

Option C. Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position: This is true and allows for flexibility depending on the patient's condition and biopsy site.

 

Option D. Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease: This is true and one of the key indications for bone marrow biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A platelet count of <40,000 is not an absolute contraindication for bone marrow biopsy, as platelet transfusion can be performed to mitigate bleeding risk.

 

Source - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger
Loss of sensation at the tip of radial tubercle
Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft

questions.text: Lesion of the structure marked '11' causes: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger

 

The structure marked 11 in the diagram is median nerve in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the median nerve causes loss of sensation of the nail of the index finger.

 

Anterior view of the right cubital fossa. The structures marked in the given image are:

 

  1. Branch of the median nerve to the brachialis muscle
  2. Biceps brachii muscle
  3. Brachialis muscle
  4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of fore arm
  5. Superficial branch of the radial nerve
  6. Brachioradialis muscle
  7. Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle
  8. Pronator teres muscle
  9. Brachial artery
  10. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm
  11. Median nerve.

 

 

Median nerve cutaneous supply:

 

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

 

Cubital fossa boundaries

 

  • An essential point of transition between the arm and the forearm is the cubital fossa. It is a triangle depression produced between two forearm muscles that is anterior to the elbow joint:
  • the brachioradialis muscle originating from the lateral supraepicondylar ridge of the humerus;
  • the pronator teres muscle originating from the medial epicondyle of the humerus

 

Contents of cubital fossa: (From medial to lateral) - "MBBS"

 

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery
  • Biceps brachi tendon
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypothenar muscles wasting: The hypothenar muscles are primarily innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve. Therefore, injury to the median nerve would not directly result in the wasting of these muscles.

 

Option C. Loss of sensation at the tip of the radial tubercle: The radial tubercle refers to the styloid process of the radius, which is not typically innervated by the median nerve. Sensory loss in this area is more likely associated with a different nerve, such as the radial nerve.

 

Option D. Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft: The median nerve supplies sensory fibers to the radial half of the ring finger, so an injury to the median nerve could result in sensory loss in the 4th interdigital cleft (between the ring finger and the little finger).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The median nerve supplies sensory fibers to the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and the radial half of the ring finger. This means that an injury to the median nerve can lead to sensory loss in these areas, including the nail of the index finger.

choices.text: A patient with sickle cell disease
A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.text: A new vaccine has been developed to target the 23 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae. This polysaccharide vaccine promises to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with pneumococcal infections, particularly in certain high-risk groups. Which of the following patient groups would most likely derive the most benefit from this vaccine? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A patient with sickle cell disease 

 

  • The polysaccharide vaccine targeting Streptococcus pneumoniae (PPSV-23) provides the greatest advantages to individuals with sickle cell disease.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is a bacteria enveloped in a protective layer that the spleen recognizes and eliminates.
  • However, in the case of sickle cell disease, the distorted shape of red blood cells obstructs the spleen's blood vessels, leading to damage.
  • This compromised spleen function, known as hyposplenism, raises the susceptibility to pneumococcal infections.
  • Consequently, sickle cell patients receive the pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV-23) as a preventive measure, aimed at diminishing this vulnerability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A child < 2 years: Polysaccharide vaccines are not effective in children under 2 years old due to their immature immune systems. Conjugate vaccines are preferred for this age group.

 

Option C. A patient with cystic fibrosis: While at risk for lung infections, cystic fibrosis patients benefit more from vaccines targeting typical respiratory pathogens, and their spleen function is usually normal.

 

Option D. A patient with recurrent otitis media: This condition is typically managed with other interventions, and the need for a polysaccharide vaccine is less critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The PPSV-23 vaccine is most beneficial for patients with sickle cell disease due to their increased susceptibility to pneumococcal infections caused by compromised spleen function.

questions.text: Which cells are not present in the layer marked as D? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Langerhans cells

 

  • The layer marked as D is stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are not present in stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are predominantly present in stratum spinosum.
  • Keratinocytes, Merkel cells & Melanocytes are all seen in Stratum Basale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratinocytes: Keratinocytes are the most prevalent cells in the epidermis and are definitely found in the stratum basale. They are responsible for the production of keratin, a key structural protein in the skin.

 

Option B. Merkel cells: Merkel cells are mechanoreceptor cells that are present in the basal layer of the epidermis. They are involved in the sensation of light touch.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes are also present in the stratum basale. These cells produce melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color and provides protection against UV radiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.4

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure is fornix which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

 

The optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, hypothalamus, para-olfactory regions, and cingulate gyrus are all supplied by the anteromedial central branches of the anterior cerebral artery in addition to the fornix.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that plays a crucial role in memory and cognitive functions. It is supplied by

 

  1. Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA): The ACA is one of the major arteries of the Circle of Willis and is responsible for supplying blood to the frontal lobes of the brain, including the anterior part of the fornix.
  2. Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA): The PCA is another major artery of the Circle of Willis, and its branches supply blood to the posterior part of the fornix.
  3. Anterior Choroidal Artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies blood to the choroid plexus in the lateral and third ventricles of the brain. It also sends branches to the fornix, particularly the inferior part.
  4. Septal Branches: The fornix also receives blood supply from septal branches, which originate from the anterior cerebral arteries. Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: By which mechanism does gene repair occur when mediated by CRISPR-Cas9?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-Homologous End joining

 

Common repair mechanism in mammalian cells.

 

  • Error-prone: It can introduce insertions or deletions (indels) at the cut site.
  • This mechanism is frequently used in CRISPR-Cas9 to disrupt gene function (gene knock-out).

 

Many clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9)-based genome editing technologies take advantage of Cas nucleases to induce DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) at desired locations within a genome. Further processing of the DSBs by the cellular DSB repair machinery is then necessary to introduce desired mutations, sequence insertions, or gene deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision: This repair mechanism corrects single-base lesions that do not significantly distort the DNA helix, typically involving the removal of damaged bases by glycosylases followed by endonuclease action.

 

Option C. Homologous End Joining: This term is not commonly used in the context of DSB repair. The correct term would be Homologous Recombination (HR), which is an accurate repair mechanism but not the predominant one in CRISPR-Cas9-mediated repairs.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair: This mechanism corrects base-pair mismatches and small insertion/deletion loops formed during DNA replication and recombination, but it is not primarily involved in repairing DSBs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 mediated gene repair primarily occurs through Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ), an error-prone repair process that ligates broken DNA ends together, often resulting in small insertions or deletions at the repair site.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylbutyrate

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate can bind ammonia to form glutamine, it does not directly reduce ammonia levels through excretion.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: An amino acid that does not have a role in reducing ammonia levels in urea cycle disorders.

 

Option D. L-carnitine: Involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation, but it does not play a role in reducing ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to reduce ammonia levels by converting ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: ABCDE rule is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant melanoma

 

ABCDE rule applies to malignant melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABCDE rule for the clinical evaluation of malignant melanoma:

 

A - Asymmetry: One half of the mole does not match the other half.

 

B - Border irregularity: The edges of the mole are irregular, ragged, or blurred.

 

C - Color variation: The mole has different shades of color, such as black, brown, tan, or red.

 

D - Diameter: The mole is larger than 6 millimeters or has grown in size.

 

E - Evolution: The mole has changed in size, shape, or color, or has started to bleed, itch, or crust over.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below. The given FFA is characteristic of which of the following? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macular ischemia

 

  • The FFA image shows features suggestive of macular ischemia (see the images below).
  • The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyper fluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in the disc region and elsewhere.

 

 

  • The FFA is showing enlarged fovea avascular zone arrow (white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow).
  • Both of which are suggestive of macular ischemia which when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards diabetic macular ischemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macular edema: shows the characteristic petaloid appearance.

 

Option C. Submacular/subretinal hemorrhage: obscure the choroidal dye visualization in the corresponding area, appearing similar to capillary non-perfusion but spreads across vascular zones without a defined pattern. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however, be visualized.

 

Option D. Premacular hemorrhage/ vitreous hemorrhage: obscure the visualization of even retinal vasculature and would appear as a region of hypo fluorescence with no retinal vasculature visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macular ischemia in diabetic patients can be identified in FFA images by an enlarged foveal avascular zone and visible areas of capillary non-perfusion, key indicators of decreased vascular supply to the macula.

questions.text: Which of the following has protective as well as lubricating property? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucin

 

Mucins form a protective barrier on epithelial surfaces. They are also found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory and urogenital tract. They also have lubricating properties.

 

Functions of Mucin:

  1. Membrane-bound mucins participate in various cell-cell interactions.
  2. Protective barrier on epithelial surfaces.
  3. Lubricating properties.
  4. "Mask" certain surface antigens.
  5. Mucins also carry cancer-specific peptide and carbohydrate epitopes.

 

Salient features of Mucin:

  1. Found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory, and reproductive tracts and also in membranes of various cells.
  2. Exhibit high content of O-glycan chains, usually containing NeuAc.
  3. Contain repeating amino acid sequences rich in serine, threonine, and proline.
  4. Extended structure contributes to their high viscoelasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collagen: Collagen provides structural support and strength to tissues but does not have significant lubricating properties.

 

Option C. Albumin: Albumin is a major plasma protein involved in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting various substances but does not have lubricating properties.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin: Immunoglobulins are antibodies that play a crucial role in immune response but do not provide lubrication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucins have both protective and lubricating properties, forming a barrier on epithelial surfaces and reducing friction in various body tracts. They are essential for maintaining the integrity and function of mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: A patient presents with scoliosis. X-ray shown below. Identify the likely cause:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital

 

Explanation:

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)

 

CONGENITAL SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Congenital scoliosis is the most frequent congenital deformity of the spine.
  • Congenital curvatures are due to anomalous development of the vertebrae (failure of formation and/or segmentation).
  • In most cases, congenital scolioses are non-hereditary.
  • It is believed to be related to an insult to the fetus during spine embryological development (between the 5th-8th week of gestation).
  • 25% of curves are non-progressive, 25% mildly progressive and 50% highly progressive and will require treatment.
  • The mainstay of treatment is either observation or surgery.
  • The rigidity of the curve is assessed, and the rib hump measured.
  • Associated malformations must be looked for clinically: look for foot or leg asymmetry, craniofacial malformation, a Klippel-Feil web neck, and cardiac and urinary malformations.
  • Full-body-width Postero-anterior (PA) and lateral X-rays are essential.
  • After 1 year of age, X-rays should be taken standing, with the legs in extension and the pelvis level, to compensate for any leg length discrepancy.
  • The Cobb angle will be measured.
  • CT scans shows a bony bar.
  • Congenital scoliosis can be classified into defect of formation or defect of segmentation:
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra (two growth plates) with a contralateral bar
    • Unilateral unsegmented bar
    • Two consecutives fully segmented hemivertebrae
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra
    • Semi segmented hemivertebra
    • Wedge vertebra (partial failure of formation)
    • Incarcerated hemivertebra (smaller and induce little deformity as the hemivertebra sits in a non-growing block; the alignment of the pedicles usually remains straight)

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment consists of either observation of the curve or surgery, or, rarely, bracing.
    • Observation should be applied only for non-progressive curves with a balanced spine.
    • Bracing is inefficient in congenital scoliosis. It may be indicated for long flexible curves or to control the compensatory lumbar curve or help rebalancing the spine, or it may be used after an operation, for instance, until the fusion is solid.
    • Surgery is the mainstay of care.
    • Prophylactic surgery:  surgery that will prevent further worsening or allow progressive correction over time. These operations are in situ fusion and hemi epiphysiodesis.
    • In situ fusion can be done with a single posterior fusion, with or without instrumentation or with an anterior fusion, or a 360° fusion.

 

 

  • Hemiepiphysiodesis tends to achieve progressive correction over time, taking advantage of the intact growth plates on the concave side of the deformity.  It has to be done ideally before the age of 5 to take advantage of the growth potential of the spine to allow a progressive correction of the deformity. It should not be carried out if there is a kyphosis component to the deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic. Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial. It is grouped by age. In children age 3 and younger, it is called infantile scoliosis. In age 4-10, it is called juvenile scoliosis. In age >10, it is called adolescent scoliosis. Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending (Adams test) as opposed to postural scoliosis. Compensatory curve due to limb length discrepancy or sciatic list (due to disc prolapsed) disappear on sitting.  Postural scoliosis disappears on forward bending.

 

Option C. Neuromuscular. This type is caused by a nervous system problem such as cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, and polio. It may present at any age; and in many cases progresses relentlessly, particularly in patients with more severe neurologic and systemic involvement. Progressive deformity may limit mobility and seating status, and may be associated with primary or secondary effects on cardiopulmonary function over time. Management includes observation, non-operative interventions such as bracing, specialized seating systems, and surgery.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis. It is hereditary, hamartomatous disorder, that affects central and peripheral nervous system, skeletal, skin and deeper soft tissue. It is one of the commonest single gene disorder affecting the skeletal system. Clinical presentation includes-cafe au lait spots (most common feature) axillary, and inguinal freckling (2nd m.c), cutaneous neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas (~5% are premalignant), Lisch nodule on iris, veruccous hyperplasia (thickened overgrown valvety soft skin), elephantiasis (pachy- dermatocele), optic glioma, skeletal abnormalities (scoliosis, congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia, hemihypertrophy) and cognitive deficits (learning disability).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows hemivertebra and block vertebra, which are characteristic of congenital type of scoliosis.

choices.text: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
5-12 years is a high-risk group

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5-12 years is a high-risk group

 

People at greater risk of severe disease or complications when infected are:

 

  1. pregnant women
  2. Children under 59 months
  3. Elderly
  4. Individuals with chronic medical conditions (such as chronic cardiac, pulmonary, renal, metabolic, neurodevelopmental, liver or hematologic diseases)
  5. Individuals with immunosuppressive conditions (such as HIV/AIDS, receiving chemotherapy or steroids, or malignancy).
  6. Health care workers are at high risk acquiring influenza virus infection due to increased exposure to the patients and risk further spread particularly to vulnerable individuals.

 

Mode of transmission – droplet infection

 

Incubation period – 1 to 4 days

 

Contagious period - About one day before developing any symptoms and up to seven days after the symptoms resolve.

 

Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza or bird flu refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR), defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (i.e., household or close contacts), can provide an indication of how social interactions relate to transmission risk. It is 5- 15% for influenza.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Virus shedding is present before symptoms begin: This is true. Influenza can be contagious before symptoms appear, which contributes to its rapid spread.

 

Option C. Aquatic birds act as a reservoir: This is true. Birds, especially aquatic birds, act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza, or bird flu, refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

Option D. Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: This is true. The secondary attack rate (SAR) for influenza, defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (e.g., household or close contacts), is typically between 5-15%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children under 5 years, pregnant women, the elderly, individuals with chronic medical conditions or immunosuppressive conditions, and health care workers are at greater risk of severe disease or complications from influenza. The 5-12 years age group is not specifically categorized as high-risk for severe disease from influenza.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with viral myositis. Viral myositis is an inflammation of the muscles caused by viral infection, often following an upper respiratory tract illness. The condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Recent viral illness: The history of fever and cough 3 days prior suggests a preceding viral infection, which is a common trigger for viral myositis.
  • Leg pain and muscle tenderness: Viral myositis often presents with significant muscle soreness, especially in the calf muscles, leading to pain on palpation.
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels: The CK level of 2000 IU indicates muscle injury or inflammation, which is consistent with viral myositis.
  • Normal reflexes and neurological examination: This helps differentiate viral myositis from other conditions like Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) or Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which would typically present with abnormal reflexes or progressive muscle weakness.

 

Influenza is a common viral cause of myositis, particularly in children. The muscle pain typically begins 1-7 days after the onset of the viral illness and may lead to difficulty walking, often with a characteristic toe-walking gait due to involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, typically presenting with proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, and elevated CK levels. However, it does not present acutely following a viral illness and usually starts earlier in life.

 

Option C. GBS (Guillain-Barré Syndrome): GBS is an autoimmune condition that causes ascending paralysis, starting with weakness in the legs. Reflexes are usually diminished or absent in GBS, unlike the normal reflexes observed in this case.

 

Option D. Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It usually presents with chronic, progressive weakness rather than acute pain following a viral illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text: The patient developed pigmentation on the nose after experiencing fever and joint pain, which appeared shortly after taking NSAIDs as shown below. What would be the likely diagnosis in this case? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig: Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Lichen planus:

 

  • Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes, presenting as itchy, purple, polygonal, flat-topped papules.
  • It is not usually associated with the intake of NSAIDs and the subsequent appearance of pigmented lesions in the described manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

questions.text: All of the following supply the structure marked ‘E’ except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Diagonal artery

 

The right ventricle is the marked object. The diagonal arterial supply does not reach it.

 

The anterior interventricular artery, which supplies the left ventricle, has a branch called the diagonal artery. Between 30 to 50 percent of the population has this.

 

The right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery, provide the right ventricle with the majority of its blood.

 

One or two anterior right ventricular branches emerge from the anterior interventricular artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right coronary artery: This is correct in terms of not being an exception. The right coronary artery primarily supplies the right atrium and the right ventricle, including the structure marked as 'E', which is the right ventricle.

 

Option B. Anterior interventricular artery: This artery primarily supplies the interventricular septum and the anterior walls of both ventricles. Although it predominantly serves the left ventricle, it also sends branches such as the anterior right ventricular branches that can reach the right ventricle.

 

Option C. Marginal artery: This artery, a branch of the right coronary artery, specifically supplies the right ventricle, which is the structure marked as 'E'.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the vascular supply of the heart is crucial, especially in clinical settings dealing with coronary artery disease. The right ventricle is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery. The diagonal artery, a branch of the left coronary system (specifically the anterior interventricular artery), mainly supplies the left ventricle and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the right ventricle.

choices.text: Involves degranulation of mast cells
Can occur on first exposure
Most commonly caused by NSAIDs

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE mediated

 

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are defined as those reactions that produce the same clinical picture with anaphylaxis but are not IgE mediated, occur through a direct nonimmune-mediated release of mediators from mast cells and/or basophils or result from direct complement activation.
  • Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

 

According to World allergy organization (WAO) anaphylaxis guidance 2020

 

IgE-mediated anaphylaxis is considered the classic and most frequent mechanism. In this type, anaphylaxis is triggered by the interaction of an allergen (usually a protein) interacting with the allergen-specific IgE/high-affinity receptor (FcεRI) complex expressed on effector cells, predominantly mast cells and basophils. This initiates intracellular signaling resulting in the release of preformed and de novo synthesis of mediators.

 

Non–IgE-mediated anaphylaxis may be immunologic or non-immunologic

 

  • Non-IgE-mediated immunologic mechanisms may involve the activation of pathways such as the complement system (anaphylatoxins, C3a, and C5a), the contact and coagulation system activation or immunoglobulin G (IgG)- mediated anaphylaxis.
  • Non-immunologic mechanisms have been described for some drugs (opioids). Ethanol and physical factors, such as exercise, may be involved in triggering anaphylaxis through mechanisms which are not fully elucidated. Mast cells may be activated through receptors by certain drugs such as neuromuscular blocking agents and fluoroquinolones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Involves degranulation of mast cells: This is true for both anaphylaxis and anaphylactoid reactions, where mast cells release histamine and other mediators, leading to the symptoms.

 

Option C. Can occur on first exposure: This is true for anaphylactoid reactions, as they do not require prior exposure or sensitization to the allergen.

 

Option D. Most commonly caused by NSAIDs: This is true. NSAIDs are a common cause of anaphylactoid reactions, which can occur without prior exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated and can occur on first exposure to the triggering substance, with NSAIDs being one of the common causes.

questions.text: Which of the following structures given below is related to the structure highlighted green in image? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pudendal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in green is the ischial spine and the pudendal nerve is related to it.

 

The ischial spine is a bony projection from the posterior part of the ischium in the pelvis

 

The pudendal nerve originates from the sacral plexus S2-S4. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor by passing around the ischial spine. The ischial spine is used as a landmark for pudendal nerve block.

 

 

  1. Sensory function: The pudendal nerve provides sensation to the external genitalia, perineum, and anus.
  2. Motor function: The pudendal nerve also supplies motor function to the pelvic floor muscles, including the external anal sphincter, bulbospongiosus muscle, and ischiocavernosus muscle.
  3. Sexual function: The pudendal nerve plays a crucial role in sexual function by supplying motor and sensory innervation to the genital organs.
  4. Urinary and fecal continence: The pudendal nerve is involved in maintaining urinary and fecal continence by controlling the external anal sphincter muscle. Damage to the pudendal nerve can lead to incontinence, which is the loss of control over urinary or fecal elimination.Top of Form

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and originates from the sacral plexus (L4-S3). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, below the piriformis muscle. While it is near the ischial spine, it descends posteriorly down the thigh, dividing into the tibial and common fibular (peroneal) nerves. It provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior thigh and most of the leg and foot. Its relation to the ischial spine is less clinically significant than the pudendal nerve's.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen and provides sensory and motor innervation to the medial thigh. In terms of its relationship to the ischial spine, it is anatomically distinct, as it courses more anteriorly in the pelvis, and it doesn't have significant clinical associations with the ischial spine.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve also originates from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It descends through the psoas muscle and enters the thigh beneath the inguinal ligament. It provides motor innervation to the anterior thigh muscles and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. The femoral nerve's course is anterior in the pelvis, and it doesn't have a direct relationship or significant clinical association with the ischial spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pudendal nerve arises from the sacral plexus (S2-S4 nerve roots). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, just inferior to the piriformis muscle. It then courses around the ischial spine and re-enters the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen. The pudendal nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineal region and external genitalia. Due to its proximity to the ischial spine, the pudendal nerve can be blocked for pain relief during childbirth and certain surgical procedures in the perineal region.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked by red arrow in the image below? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the superior oblique muscle. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

 

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

 

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

 

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) except Superior Oblique (Trochlear nerve, IV) and Lateral rectus (Abducens, VI)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve: This nerve innervates most of the extraocular muscles except for the superior oblique and the lateral rectus. It does not innervate the structure marked in the image, which is the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve: This nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the face and does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the superior oblique.

 

Option D. Abducens nerve: This nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle only, which abducts the eye. It does not innervate the superior oblique muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle, is uniquely innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which is the only cranial nerve that exits the brainstem dorsally. This muscle functions to depress, abduct, and internally rotate the eyeball, and it is the only extraocular muscle innervated by the trochlear nerve. Remembering this specific innervation is crucial for diagnosing and managing ocular motility disorders.

questions.text:
Steps of surgery of DDH in a child < 2 years:(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Capsulotomy
  2. Femoral osteotomy
  3. Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament
  4. Placing the head back into acetabulum
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a → c → b → d

 

DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)

 

  • This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during or shortly after birth.
  • DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malformations of acetabulum or femur.
  • More common in girls usually seen on left side.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment:

    • Surgical approach: 
      • The aim in DDH is to place the head of femur in acetabulum. 
      • Open the joint, identify the acetabulum, cut and rotate the femur and place the head in acetabulum.
    • Surgical procedure:
      • Percutaneous adductor tenotomy is performed in all patients prior to open reduction. 
      • The hip joint is approached superficially between sartorius and tensor fascia lata. 
      • The sartorius is detached from anterior superior iliac spine to improve exposure. 
      • The anteromedial capsule is incised to remove the obstacle to reduction. 
      • The femoral head is identified and ligamentum teres is cut and traced to the acetabulum. 
      • The psoas tendon is identified and tenotomy is done to improve access to the acetabulum. 
      • The acetabular labrum is identified and care is taken to keep it intact and undamaged. 
      • The transverse acetabular ligament is identified and incised to remove the inferior obstacle to reduction. 
      • The acetabulum is cleared of fibrocartilaginous tissue and femoral head is reduced into the acetabulum. 

     

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of surgical procedure for DDH in a child < 2 years of age is: 

Capsulotomy

↓

Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament

↓

Femoral osteotomy

↓

Placing the head back into acetabulum

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dexamethasone

 

Dexamethasone is utilized in the treatment of hypercalcemia, particularly when induced by Vitamin D toxicity. This corticosteroid helps reduce calcium absorption from the intestine and increase calcium excretion, effectively lowering serum calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: Used primarily as an antimalarial and in autoimmune diseases, it does not play a role in managing hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Hydroxychloroquine: Similar to chloroquine, used for autoimmune disorders but not for hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Ketoconazole: An antifungal medication that can reduce corticosteroid production but is not specifically used to treat hypercalcemia caused by Vitamin D toxicity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone, Bisphosphonates, IV fluids, Loop diuretics, Calcitonin are used in the management of Hypercalcemia.

 

Reference - (Harrison/Endocrinology/Hypercalcemia)

questions.text: Match the following:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-5, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Madelung deformity involves distal radius.  It is the volar translation of the wrist. It is seen associated with Turner Syndrome.

 

 

B. Haglund deformity is the bony prominence over calcaneum and the overlying retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

C. Buttonhole deformity is the abnormal extension at distal interphalangeal joint and flexion at proximal interphalangeal joint and is seen with Rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

D. Gunstock deformity is seen in Cubitus varus. It is a complication frequently seen after untreated supracondylar fracture of humerus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apoptosis

 

Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are both seen in apoptosis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Necrosis: Necrosis is a form of traumatic cell death that results from acute cellular injury. It is characterized by uncontrolled cell lysis, inflammation, and the release of intracellular contents into the extracellular space. Necrosis does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways seen in apoptosis.

 

Option C. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrosis that is caspase-independent but involves the receptor-interacting protein kinases (RIPK1 and RIPK3). It is similar to necrosis but is regulated and has distinct signaling pathways that do not include the intrinsic or extrinsic apoptotic pathways.

 

Option D. Pyroptosis: Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death associated with inflammation, typically involving caspase-1, which processes pro-inflammatory cytokines. It does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptosis is characterized by both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, which lead to programmed cell death in a controlled and regulated manner.

questions.text: A 33-week multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, proteinuria: 3+. The next step of management would be? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MgSO4 IV

 

In the scenario of imminent eclampsia, neuro-prophylaxis with Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4) is recommended. Imminent eclampsia is characterized by symptoms such as severe headaches, visual disturbances, epigastric pain, and hyperreflexia, indicating that the woman is at high risk of developing seizures (eclampsia). MgSO4 is effective in preventing seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia and imminent eclampsia, as supported by the Magpie Trial, which is the largest comparative study demonstrating its efficacy.

 

The Magpie Trial (MgSO4 for Prevention of Eclampsia) showed that MgSO4 prophylaxis in women with severe pre-eclampsia effectively prevented the development of eclampsia, making it the standard of care for neuro-prophylaxis in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is an antenatal steroid used to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. It is administered in doses of 6 mg every 12 hours for a total of four doses. However, it is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option B. Betamethasone: Betamethasone, like dexamethasone, is also an antenatal steroid given to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. The typical regimen is 12 mg administered 24 hours apart for two doses. It is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option D. LSCS: The mode of delivery, whether vaginal or Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS), will depend on the status of the cervical os and other obstetric indications. LSCS is not a prophylactic measure for preventing eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is recommended for neuro-prophylaxis in women with severe or imminent eclampsia to prevent seizures.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1840

questions.text: What type of mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point mutations

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused due to a point mutation in B globin gene wherein adenine is replaced with thymine in the 6th codon of DNA sequence. Thus, the glutamic acid in the 6th position of beta chain of HbA is changed to valine in HbS. This single amino acid substitution leads to polymerization of hemoglobin molecules inside RBCs. This causes a distortion of cell into sickle shape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insertion: An insertion mutation involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Deletion: A deletion mutation involves the removal of one or more nucleotide base pairs from the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option D. Frameshift mutation: A frameshift mutation is caused by insertions or deletions of a number of nucleotides that are not divisible by three, resulting in a shift in the reading frame of the codons in the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jackson-Pratt drain

 

The image displays a Jackson-Pratt (JP) drain, which is a type of closed drainage system used in post-surgical procedures. This device comprises a flexible bulb connected to tubing, creating negative pressure to gently suction fluid from the wound or surgical site. The bulb can be compressed and then sealed to initiate suction, allowing controlled drainage and reducing the risk of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Romovac drain: Romovac drains are commonly used after various surgical procedures, including abdominal surgeries, breast surgeries, orthopedic surgeries, and others. They are also utilized in the treatment of abscesses and some types of traumatic injuries. They are a closed drainage system.

 

 

Option C. Minivac drain – (Mini in size): A closed suction drain is placed under your skin during surgery. This drain removes any blood or other fluids that might build up in this area.

 

 

Option D. Corrugated drain: Corrugated drains are intended for open passive drainage, used in situations where wounds must be kept open. They are placed directly into the wounds left to heal by secondary intent. 

 

 

Educational Objective : 

 

The Jackson-Pratt drain is a closed drainage system that uses gentle suction to remove fluids from surgical sites, helping prevent fluid accumulation and reducing infection risk.

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2nd Palmar interossei

 

The dorsal digital extension of the middle finger is the structure indicated in the picture. The middle finger's dorsal digital extension is not aided by the palmar interossei because they do not attach to the middle finger.

 

The palmar interossei muscles are also located between the metacarpal bones but are found on the palmar side of the hand. Their primary function is to adduct the fingers. Unlike the dorsal interossei, the palmar interossei insert only into the bases of the proximal phalanges and do not extend to the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd palmar interosseous does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Extensor hoods, also known as "dorsal digital expansions," are formed when the tendons of the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus muscles cross over the dorsal aspect of the digits and extend over the proximal phalanges. These hoods are connected by the tendons of the extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis muscles.

 

 

 

The dorsal digital expansion, also known as the extensor hood or extensor expansion, is a complex aponeurotic structure found on the dorsal aspect of each finger. It serves as the insertion point for certain tendons and allows the extensor tendons to provide extension at all three finger joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd Dorsal interossei: The dorsal interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones and are primarily responsible for the abduction of the fingers. There are four dorsal interossei in the hand. The tendons of the dorsal interossei insert into the bases of the proximal phalanges and into the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd dorsal interosseous does contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option B. Lumbricals: The lumbricals are four small muscles in the hand that arise from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons. Their primary function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. The tendons of the lumbricals insert into the dorsal digital expansion on the radial sides of the fingers. Hence, lumbricals do contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: The extensor digitorum muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. It extends down the forearm and sends tendons to the fingers. These tendons attach to the dorsal digital expansion and primarily facilitate the extension of the fingers. Thus, the extensor digitorum directly contributes to the formation of the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal digital expansion plays a key role in extending the finger joints and is formed by the integration of tendons from several muscles, excluding the 2nd Palmar interossei, which primarily functions in adduction and does not extend to the dorsal side of the fingers.

questions.text: Where do afferent fibers from baroreceptors primarily project for blood pressure control? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

 

Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS).

 

The afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control primarily project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS). The NTS is located in the medulla oblongata, which is part of the brainstem. It serves as the primary site for integrating and processing information related to blood pressure regulation.

 

The baroreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the walls of certain blood vessels, particularly in the carotid sinus and aortic arch. These receptors detect changes in blood pressure and relay this information via afferent (sensory) nerve fibers. The afferent fibers from the baroreceptors transmit signals to the NTS, where they are integrated and contribute to the regulation of blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleus ambiguous: Incorrect. This nucleus is involved in controlling the muscles of the pharynx, larynx, and soft palate.

 

Option B. Rostral-ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in the regulation of sympathetic outflow but does not receive direct input from baroreceptor afferents.

 

Option D. Caudal ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in regulating blood pressure but is not the primary projection site for baroreceptor afferents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Afferent fibers from baroreceptors project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) in the medulla oblongata, where they integrate and process information related to blood pressure regulation.

choices.text: Child Welfare Committee

questions.text: A young girl refuses to go to Mathematics class everyday citing abnormal excuses. It was discovered by the principal that the mathematics teacher was touching her genitalia inappropriately. The duty of the principal is to report this to?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Police

 

Explanation:

 

Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, the principal should refer to Section 19 which states that “Any person who has apprehension that an offence under this Act is likely to be committed or has knowledge that such an offence has been committed shall provide such information to the Special Juvenile Police Unit or the local police.”

 

Other options

 

Option A) Magistrate, Option C) child welfare committee, Option D) Parents: According to POCSO Act, Article 19, the immediate duty is to inform the police when there is knowledge or apprehension of a child being sexually abused. Others can be informed later.

 

Educational Objective

 

POCSO Act Provisions

 

  • Section 19 of the Act makes it mandatory for any person including the child to approach the police in case of an apprehension that an offence under the Act is likely to be committed or "has the knowledge" that such an act has been committed.

 

 The POCSO act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offenses which include:

 

  • ﻿﻿﻿Sexual harassment - Threatening
  • ﻿﻿﻿Sexual assault - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated sexual assault - Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  • ﻿﻿﻿Penetrative sexual assault - An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration of the penis or any object into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated penetrative sexual assault - Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  • ﻿﻿﻿Pornography

choices.text: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus
It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria
It promotes the growth of pseudomonas

questions.text: The CLED medium is preferred over other media for the culture of organisms in case of UTI because: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It inhibits proteus swarming

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

 

Proteus species are a common cause of UTI and produce swarming on ordinary medias leading to difficult isolation of other important urinary pathogens

 

Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, it changes to yellow in case of acid production during fermentation of lactose or changes to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria build yellow colonies. Bacteria which decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and build deep blue colonies.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus. CLED media does not specifically promote the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus.
 

 

Option C. It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria: This is also true for CLED medium but not the reason why it is specifically used for urinary pathogens. Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, changing to yellow in case of acid production during lactose fermentation or to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria form yellow colonies, while bacteria that decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and form deep blue colonies.

 

Option D. It promotes the growth of Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can grow on CLED medium, it is not specifically promoted by this medium compared to the growth of Candida, Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

choices.text: Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents to the ER with confusion and shaking of the entire body. He has a history of excessive alcohol consumption. What is the cause of delirium tremens in an alcoholic? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute infection

 

Delirium tremens is primarily caused by abrupt alcohol cessation in chronic users.

 

Acute infections can exacerbate or precipitate its onset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fatty liver: Fatty liver doesn't directly precipitate DT.

 

Option C. Gradual withdrawal of alcohol: Gradual withdrawal typically avoids DT.

 

Option D. Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol: Regular small doses wouldn't lead to abrupt cessation symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 572-573.

questions.text: Identify which of these is not a component of qSOFA? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral absent pupillary reflex

 

qSOFA stands for Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment. It is a simplified bedside clinical tool used to quickly assess the risk of organ failure and sepsis in patients. qSOFA includes three Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Respiratory Rate ≥ 22/min: A respiratory rate of 22 or higher per minute suggests abnormal breathing and is one of the criteria in qSOFA.
  2. Altered Mental Status: Altered mental status, such as confusion or disorientation, is also a component of qSOFA. It reflects the patient's neurological status and helps in evaluating the severity of illness.
  3. Systolic Blood Pressure < 100 mm Hg: A systolic blood pressure (BP) less than 100 mm Hg indicates poor perfusion and is another parameter in qSOFA.

 

Derangement in 2 or 3 components carries high mortality.

 

Option D: Bilateral absent pupillary reflex: Not a component of qSOFA. The qSOFA score does not include any criteria related to pupillary reflexes. Bilateral absent pupillary reflex is more relevant to assessing brainstem function or neurological assessment rather than organ failure related to sepsis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

qSOFA includes three criteria for assessing sepsis risk: respiratory rate ≥ 22/min, systolic BP < 100 mm Hg, and altered mental status. It does not include pupillary reflex assessment.

choices.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Need antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

questions.text: Which of the following about γδ T-cells is incorrect? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Need antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

 

γδ T-cells do not need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition.

 

There are two types of T cells: γδ T-cells and αβ T-cells.

 

  • The functions of γδ T-cells:
    • Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages
    • Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
    • Plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance
    • Capable of recognizing and lying diverse cancers in an MHC-unrestricted manner
  • The αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are displayed by major histocompatibility complex (MHC. molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). By limiting the specificity of T cells for peptides displayed by cell surface MHC molecules, called MHC restriction, the immune system ensures that T cells see only cell-associated antigens (e.g., those derived from microbes in cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin: This is correct and one of the key functions of γδ T-cells.

 

Option C. Direct killing of infected macrophages: This is correct, as γδ T-cells can directly target and kill infected cells.

 

Option D. Provide protection against mycobacteria: This is correct; γδ T-cells play an important role in defense against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

γδ T-cells do not require antigen processing and presentation by MHC molecules for their recognition, unlike αβ T-cells, making them unique in their ability to directly recognize and respond to a variety of antigens.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 352-353

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endothelial cells

 

vWF is made in endothelial cells and megakaryocytes. vWF is also present in the subendothelial matrix of normal blood vessels and the α-granules of platelets. Following endothelial injury, exposure of subendothelial vWF causes adhesion of platelets, primarily via the glycoprotein lb (GpIB) platelet receptor.

 

  • Endothelial cells are responsible for producing and secreting the majority of plasma vWF. They synthesize vWF and store it in Weibel-Palade bodies, specialized storage granules in the endothelial cells. Upon vascular injury, vWF is released into the bloodstream, where it binds to platelets and subendothelial structures, facilitating the formation of a platelet plug.
  • Additionally, megakaryocytes synthesize vWF, which is stored in the alpha granules of platelets and released during platelet activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelets: While platelets contain vWF in their alpha granules and release it upon activation, they are not the major source of plasma vWF. Instead, their vWF contributes to local hemostasis at the site of injury.

 

Option B. Lymphocytes: Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell involved in the immune response and do not produce or release vWF.

 

Option C. Macrophages: Macrophages are involved in phagocytosis and the immune response, but they do not produce vWF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major source of plasma von Willebrand factor (vWF) is endothelial cells, which release vWF into the bloodstream upon vascular injury to facilitate platelet adhesion.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1253

questions.text: Non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Male infertility

 

Pulsatile exposure to GnRH induces FSH/LH secretion while sustained exposure de-sensitizes the receptors resulting in decrease in secretion of gonadotropins. Therefore, non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are given when we want to decrease the sex hormones.

 

Indications:-

 

  •  Prostatic carcinoma
  •  Endometriosis
  •  Precocious puberty
  •  Fibroid

 

But in case of male infertility, more testosterone is required to induce spermatogenesis, so GnRH agonists are given in pulsatile manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: In endometriosis, continuous GnRH agonists are used to lower estrogen levels, which helps reduce the growth of endometrial tissue and alleviate symptoms.

 

Option C. Central precocious puberty: Continuous GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels, thereby delaying early onset puberty.

 

Option D. Prostate cancer: Continuous GnRH agonists reduce testosterone levels, which helps in managing prostate cancer by slowing down the growth of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels in conditions such as endometriosis, central precocious puberty, and prostate cancer. In male infertility, pulsatile GnRH agonists are used to increase testosterone and induce spermatogenesis.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 262,263

questions.text: Addison's disease is commonly associated with: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autoimmune adrenalitis

 

Addison's disease, primarily characterized by adrenal insufficiency, is most commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis. In this condition, the body's immune system attacks the adrenal cortex, leading to a decrease in the production of steroid hormones such as cortisol and aldosterone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypernephroma: Also known as renal cell carcinoma, hypernephroma is a type of kidney cancer and has no direct link to the adrenal function or Addison's disease.

 

Option C. Adrenocortical carcinoma: This is a cancer of the adrenal cortex but typically leads to excessive hormone production, associated more with Cushing's syndrome rather than Addison's disease, where there is hormone deficiency.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid: This type of cancer is associated with the thyroid gland and is related to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndrome but not directly linked to Addison's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis, where the immune system mistakenly attacks the adrenal glands, leading to insufficient production of vital hormones.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organisms shown below acts via? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ADP ribosylation of EF2

 

The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and a Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

 

Diphtheria toxin functions by selectively ADP-ribosylating ribosomal elongation factor, EF-2, attenuating protein synthesis and leading to cell death within a matter of hours. DT is a highly potent toxin. It is bacteriophage mediated.

 

NOTE: Pseudomonas toxin also inhibits protein synthesis by ADP ribosylation of EF2.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increase in cAMP: This mechanism is typically associated with toxins such as cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which lead to an increase in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) by ADP-ribosylating G proteins, but not involved in the action of diphtheria toxin.

 

Option B. Increase in cGMP: This mechanism is not relevant to diphtheria toxin but is associated with certain bacterial toxins like heat-stable enterotoxin (ST) produced by E. coli, which increases cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels.

 

Option D. RNA glycosidase: This mechanism refers to Shiga toxin and ricin, which inhibit protein synthesis by enzymatically removing adenine from rRNA, but it is not the mode of action for diphtheria toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), thereby inhibiting protein synthesis and leading to cell death.

choices.text: Repeat Inj. adenosine 6 mg
Inj. amiodarone 300 mg

questions.text: The ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchronized Cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on T phenomenon).

 

Synchronized Cardioversion is the correct choice for a hemodynamically unstable patient, as it is intended to restore normal heart rhythm without causing further cardiac risks. Synchronization ensures that the shock is delivered at a safe point in the QRS complex to prevent the induction of ventricular fibrillation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable

 

Option C. Amiodarone is used in the treatment of chronic arrhythmias and rarely for acute treatment of SVT

 

Option D. DC cardioversion technically refers to the same treatment as synchronized cardioversion in the context of unstable rhythms but the lack of specification about synchronization could imply a risk if not properly timed.

 

Synchronised cardioversion avoid possibility of R on T phenomenon.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of hemodynamically unstable tachyarrhythmias where initial pharmacological interventions fail, synchronized cardioversion should be promptly employed to stabilize the patient. This technique is crucial for preventing progression to more severe complications such as cardiac arrest.

choices.text: Washing hands with soap and water
Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.text: During a busy day at the outpatient clinic, a nurse accidentally sustains a needle stick injury while drawing blood from a patient known to have HIV. She asks for guidance on immediate management steps to mitigate her risk of acquiring the infection. Which of the following recommendations would NOT be appropriate? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administration of tenofovir monotherapy

 

  • Triple drug PEP regimens are now the recommended regimens for all exposures owing to the safety and tolerability of new HIV drugs. Tenofovir 300mg + Lamivudine 300mg + Dolutegravir 50mg is recommended for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), not monotherapy.
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV consists of a comprehensive set of services to prevent infection developing in an exposed person, including first aid care; counselling and risk assessment; HIV testing and counselling; and, depending on the risk assessment, the short term (28 days) provision of antiretroviral drugs, with support and follow-up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Washing hands with soap and water: This is an appropriate initial step.

 

Option C. Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately: This is necessary to establish the baseline and monitor for any seroconversion.

 

Option D. Measure viral markers after 6 weeks: Follow-up testing is crucial to detect any potential infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For needle stick injuries involving HIV exposure, a triple drug regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis is recommended, not monotherapy.
  • Immediate washing, baseline viral markers, and follow-up testing are also critical components of the management protocol.

questions.text: A patient of hemophilia received multiple blood transfusions. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities can be seen in a patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

Metabolic alkalosis in a patient who received multiple blood transfusions arises primarily from the metabolism of citrate, used as a preservative in stored blood products.

 

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

 

Excess citrate preservative gets converted to bicarbonate causing Metabolic alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: This condition would typically result from an accumulation of acids or loss of bicarbonate, which is not a direct consequence of blood transfusion.

 

Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis: Would involve hyperventilation leading to decreased carbon dioxide levels, unrelated to transfusion effects.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Involves hypoventilation increasing carbon dioxide levels, which is also unrelated to the effects of blood transfusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic alkalosis is a potential complication of multiple or massive blood transfusions due to the metabolism of citrate preservative into bicarbonate, emphasizing the importance of monitoring electrolytes and acid-base balance during such procedures.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Delayed complications: GVHD, PTP, Infections

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below used in laparoscopic surgeries? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The instrument in the image is Veress Needle.

 

The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. It consists of a long, slender needle with a sharp, pointed tip and a hollow center. The needle is attached to a handle and a valve that controls the flow of gas into the abdominal cavity.

 

The Veress needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity through a small incision, usually in the umbilicus (closed technique). The surgeon first lifts the abdominal wall away from the underlying organs and tissues, then inserts the Veress needle at a 45-degree angle to the skin and advances it until it reaches the abdominal cavity. The valve is then opened to allow gas (usually carbon dioxide) to flow into the abdominal cavity, creating a space for the laparoscope and other instruments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morris' needle: This is not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum or laparoscopic access.

 

Option C. Yankauer suction tip: This is a suction instrument used to clear surgical sites of blood and fluids, not for gas insufflation.

 

Option D. Von Graefe needle: Primarily used in ophthalmic procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of the Veress needle helps to minimize the risk of injury to surrounding organs and tissues during laparoscopic procedures. It is typically used at the beginning of the procedure, after which the laparoscope and other instruments are inserted through separate ports or trocars placed in the abdomen. The Veress needle is then removed and the incision closed.
