choices.text: Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A patient with renal failure develops vomiting in ICU. ABG analysis showed pH - 7.4, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L, HC03- = 24mEq/L, PaC02 = 40 mmHg. What is the likely metabolic abnormality? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

 

Clinical history of renal failure should hint towards possibility of preexisting metabolic acidosis. Important in MCQs to always calculate AG even if ABG appears normal.

 

AG: 145-(100+24) = 21 (Normal ~12)

 

Excess unmeasured anion(H) combines with HCO3 thereby reducing the HCO3 proportionately.

 

Hence Delta ratio i.e., ΔAG(AG-12) /ΔHCO3(24-HCO3) = >2.

 

Value >2 indicate coexisting Metabolic alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ABG: The pH is indeed normal, but the underlying disturbances (as reflected by an increased anion gap) indicate that the system is not normal.

 

Option B. Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis: The anion gap is increased, ruling out normal anion gap acidosis.

 

Option D. High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis: This choice incorrectly identifies the nature of acid-base disturbances, confusing the interpretation and relationship between anion gap and bicarbonate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with renal failure and symptoms like vomiting, it's crucial to evaluate both the anion gap and changes in bicarbonate to identify complex acid-base disturbances such as the coexistence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.text: A patient of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart but there is no change in her weight after 1 week. Which of the following needs to be done? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal

 

A lack of weight gain in an anorexia nervosa patient adhering to a diet can suggest surreptitious purging behaviors:

 

Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal: This helps in ensuring the patient isn't purging post-meal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-anxiety medication: Anxiety is common in anorexia but doesn't directly address potential purging.

 

Option C. Increase calories: Confirm proper consumption and retention before adjusting calories.

 

Option D. Increase water intake: This won't address the primary concern and may introduce other issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients with anorexia nervosa who are not gaining weight despite adherence to a meal plan, it's important to first rule out surreptitious purging behaviors. Observing the patient post-meal can help ensure that they are not engaging in behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise after eating.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 320.

choices.text: Direct observation with a structured checklist
In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.text: A newly established hospital aims to maintain the highest standards of care and ensure patient safety by standardizing injection practices among health workers. They seek a reliable method for real-time assessment of these practices. Which of the following would be the most appropriate method to monitor the injection practices of health workers? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Direct observation with a structured checklist

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.
  • This method allows for real-time, accurate assessment of adherence to aseptic techniques and best practices.
  • A structured checklist ensures all critical steps are monitored and recorded systematically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Closed circuit camera surveillance: While it may offer some insights, it lacks the detail and real-time assessment provided by direct observation.

 

Option C. In-depth interview with the patient: Patients may not have the expertise to accurately comment on the technical aspects of injection practices.

 

Option D. In-depth interview with the healthcare provider: This relies on self-reporting, which may be biased and not always accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.
Both the assertion and reason are true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion.
Assertion is true but the reason is false.
Assertion is false but the reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion: Ultrasonography is the primary imaging modality for the screening and diagnosis of IVH and parenchymal hemorrhage in neonates.

 

Reason: The posterior fontanelle offers a good acoustic window for imaging using USG.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true but the reason is false.

 

Ultrasonography (USG) is indeed the primary imaging modality for screening and diagnosing intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and parenchymal hemorrhage in neonates. This is because USG is non-invasive, quick, safe, and can be easily performed at the bedside, which is ideal for neonates in a critical care setting.

 

The assertion is correct, but the reason given is incorrect. The appropriate acoustic window for imaging IVH and other intracranial structures in neonates is the anterior fontanelle, not the posterior fontanelle. The anterior fontanelle provides a larger and more accessible window, which is optimal for visualizing the brain structures in detail.

 

Neonates at high risk for IVH, such as those with a gestational age below 32 weeks or a birth weight under 1500 grams, should undergo routine screening. Additionally, more mature preterm infants (32-34 weeks) should also be considered for screening if they experience complications postnatally, such as shock, unexplained anemia, or severe respiratory distress requiring mechanical ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior fontanelle, not the posterior, is the primary acoustic window used in ultrasonography for imaging intracranial structures in neonates.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of brachial plexus do not give branches? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Divisions

 

Explanation:

 

The divisions in the brachial plexus do not give any branches.

 

However, the roots, trunks, and cords of the brachial plexus give out direct branches.

 

The brachial plexus is a complex network of nerves that originates from the ventral rami of the fifth cervical to the first thoracic spinal nerves (C5-T1). The brachial plexus is typically organized into five stages: roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and terminal branches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roots: The roots of the brachial plexus are the five ventral rami (C5-T1) that serve as the origin of the brachial plexus. These roots give off several branches:

 

  • C5 root can contribute to the dorsal scapular nerve.
  • C5 and C6 roots together give rise to the upper trunk, but before they merge, they can give off the nerve to the subclavius muscle (from C5 and C6).
  • C8 and T1 roots can contribute to the long thoracic nerve along with C7 root.

 

Option B. Cords: The cords are named based on their position relative to the axillary artery: lateral, medial, and posterior cords.

 

  • The lateral cord gives branches like the lateral pectoral nerve.
  • The medial cord gives branches like the medial pectoral, medial cutaneous nerve of arm, and medial cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • The posterior cord provides branches like the upper subscapular, thoracodorsal, and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option C. Trunks: There are three trunks in the brachial plexus: upper, middle, and lower.

 

  • The upper trunk is formed by the union of C5 and C6 roots and gives off the suprascapular nerve and the nerve to the omohyoid muscle.
  • The middle and lower trunks usually do not give any significant branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each trunk divides into two divisions: an anterior division and a posterior division. The divisions do not provide any branches.

questions.text: Deep y descent in Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) is seen in all of the following conditions except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac Tamponade

 

Deep y descent in JVP (Jugular venous pressure) is a characteristic finding in several conditions that affect the filling of the right ventricle. These conditions include constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Cardiac tamponade, as it is associated with a blunted y descent in JVP rather than a deep y descent. In cardiac tamponade, the pericardial fluid accumulation restricts cardiac filling, leading to a decrease in the amplitude of the y descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This condition can cause a deep y descent due to the stiff ventricular walls allowing rapid passive filling only during early diastole.

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Similar to restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis also shows a rapid early diastolic filling as the rigid pericardium constricts ventricular filling in late diastole, leading to a pronounced y descent.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: In tricuspid regurgitation, right atrial emptying occurs without the normal resistance posed by a competent tricuspid valve, often resulting in a prominent y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the presence of fluid in the pericardial space restricts all phases of cardiac filling, leading to a blunted or absent y descent, differentiating it from conditions where a deep y descent is observed.

questions.text:
Match the items in Column A with their correct description in Column B: 

 

Column A:

1. Primary survey

2. Secondary survey

3. Definitive care

4. Resuscitation

 

Column B:
a. Make a management plan
b. Identify what can cause death
c. Identify other injuries
d. Treat what can cause death
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d


The steps outlined are part of the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) protocol, designed to assess and manage trauma patients systematically.

 

  • Primary Survey involves the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure), focusing on identifying and treating immediate life-threatening issues. It emphasizes identifying what can cause death.
  • Secondary Survey is a thorough head-to-toe evaluation after initial stabilization. This step is intended to identify other injuries that may not be immediately life-threatening.
  • Definitive Care involves creating a comprehensive treatment plan based on findings from the primary and secondary surveys, hence making a management plan.
  • Resuscitation is simultaneous with the primary survey to stabilize vital signs and provide essential interventions, focusing on treating what can cause death immediately, such as hemorrhage control and airway support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ATLS protocol steps emphasize a structured approach for trauma assessment, prioritizing immediate life-threatening conditions first, followed by a comprehensive examination and a definitive management plan.

 

  1. Primary survey - Identify what can cause death
  2. Secondary survey - Identify other injuries
  3. Definitive care - Make a management plan
  4. Resuscitation - Treat what can cause death

questions.text:
Match the snakes with the corresponding images: 

 

Column A:

1. Cobra

2. Viper

3. Python

4. Krait

 

Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C


The correct matches between Column A (snakes) and Column B (images) are based on identifying features unique to each snake:

 

  1. Cobra (1 - B): The cobra is identified by its hood and characteristic spectacle mark. In the images, Image B shows a hooded snake with this mark, which is typical of cobras.
  2. Viper (2 - D): Vipers usually have thick bodies and distinctive diamond or blotched patterns. Image D shows a snake with diamond-shaped patterns on its body, which aligns with the viper's appearance.
  3. Python (3 - A): Pythons are generally large and thick-bodied, with irregular circular markings. Image A displays these features, which are characteristic of pythons.
  4. Krait (4 - C): Kraits are slender snakes with alternating bands. Image C shows a snake with white bands on a darker body, which matches the appearance of a krait.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cobra - Hooded with spectacle mark
  • Viper - Diamond-shaped spots
  • Python - Thick and large
  • Krait - White bands on body

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD and is undergoing dialysis. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alport syndrome.

 

 

 

A, Alport syndrome (EM), Note the presence of both the characteristic “basket- weave” change (asterisks) and thinning of the GBM (arrows).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome is an immune-mediated disease characterised by antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of GBM type IV collagen; it is not hereditary, and light microscopy reveals extracapillary growth with crescents and necrosis.

 

Option C. IgA nephropathy: In IgA nephropathy, light microscopy would demonstrate focal mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis and mesangial widening.

 

Option D. PSGN:  In PSGN, light microscopy would reveal diffuse endocapillary proliferation with concomitant leukocytic infiltration in LM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, with characteristic findings on electron microscopy, including a "basket-weave" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with overdose some drug. There were increased salivation and increased bronchial secretions. On examination, blood pressure was 88/60 mmHg. RBC esterase level is 50. What should be the treatment of this person?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atropine

 

  • Low esterase levels are suggestive of overdose of some drug which acts by inhibiting acetyl choline esterase like organophosphate poisoning.
  • Inhibition of choline esterase results in increased amount of Ach at synapse, so poisoning or overdose results in cholinergic symptoms like salivation, lacrimation, urination, emesis, increased bronchial secretions, and reduction in blood pressure.
    So treatment of choice is Atropine.
  • Atropine - It is highly effective in counter-acting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects. It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action. All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly treated with atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear (upto 200 mg has been administered in a day). Continued treatment with maintenance doses may be required for 1-2 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is incorrect as it is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would worsen the cholinergic symptoms by increasing acetylcholine levels further.

 

Option C. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is incorrect because it is an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, not for organophosphate poisoning. It works by antagonizing the effects of benzodiazepines on the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is incorrect as it is also an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would exacerbate the symptoms of cholinergic overdose. Additionally, it is used to treat atropine poisoning, not organophosphate poisoning.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning, which presents with cholinergic symptoms and low RBC esterase levels, the treatment of choice is atropine, administered intravenously until signs of atropinization appear.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/122

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Botulinum

 

The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

 

Clostridium botulinum is non-invasive. Its pathogenesis is due to the production of powerful neurotoxin ‘botulinum toxin’ (BoNT). It produces flaccid paralysis. There are 7 serological types of botulinum neurotoxin labeled as types A, B, C [C1 C2], D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is caused mainly by types A, B, E and F (rarely).

 

After entry (either ingested, inhaled, or produced in a wound), botulinum toxin is transported via the blood to peripheral cholinergic nerve terminals. The most common nerve terminal sites are neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia. It does not affect the CNS.

 

Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins that are required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles, thereby preventing the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the peripheral nerve endings, including neuromuscular junctions (presynaptic inhibition). This results in a lack of stimulus to the muscle fibers, irreversible relaxation of the muscles to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal, and flaccid paralysis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tetanus: Tetanus toxin (produced by Clostridium tetani) acts by inhibiting neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system by cleaving synaptobrevin, another SNARE protein, but it causes spastic paralysis rather than flaccid paralysis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin (produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae) inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is a completely different mechanism from that of botulinum toxin.

 

Option D. Pertussis: Pertussis toxin (produced by Bordetella pertussis) modifies the signaling of G-protein coupled receptors by ADP-ribosylating the Gi protein, thereby affecting cellular communication but not directly impacting acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at peripheral nerve endings through the proteolysis of SNARE proteins necessary for acetylcholine vesicle exocytosis.

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 500-600 ml

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 500-600 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When calculating the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient, it is essential to account for approximately 500-600 ml/day of insensible water loss due to evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production

 

Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors occurs due to prolonged exposure to elevated vasopressin levels resulting in excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels, thus maintaining euvolemia and preventing excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH. This is called as vasopressin escape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in urine osmolarity: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape does not result in an increase in urine osmolarity. Instead, it is characterized by the body's ability to excrete free water to prevent hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Decrease in ADH secretion: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape occurs despite high levels of ADH, not due to a decrease in ADH secretion.

 

Option D. Upregulation of aquaporin 2 production: Incorrect. The condition involves the downregulation, not upregulation, of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone (SIADH): Pathogenesis and clinical findings

choices.text: Post mortem lividity

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Marbling

 

Explanation: In the above picture superficial veins are visible on the dead body which is characteristic of Marbling. Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color called marbling.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B) Algor mortis: Algor mortis refers to the postmortem cooling of the body. After death, the body temperature gradually decreases until it reaches the ambient temperature hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles that occurs after death due to ATP depletion in the muscles.

 

Option D) Post mortem lividity is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish. The pale looking areas on the skin are the pressure areas. The below image of PM Lividity

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Marbling

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic color change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of color change in putrefaction:
  1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
  2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color.
  1. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  2. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  3. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET) is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

Most common type of PNET seen is: Insulinoma

 

Insulinomas are the most common type of PNETs. They produce excess insulin, leading to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) in affected individuals. Insulinomas are typically benign and occur more frequently than other types of PNETs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma: Gastrinoma is a type of PNET that produces excess gastrin hormone. It is associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Gastrinomas are relatively less common than insulinomas.

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare PNETs that produce excess somatostatin hormone. They can occur in the pancreas or other parts of the digestive system. They are less common than insulinomas.

 

Option D. VIPoma: VIPomas, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome or pancreatic cholera, are PNETs that produce vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). These tumors are relatively rare compared to insulinomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PNETs are a rare type of pancreatic tumor that originate from neuroendocrine cells in the pancreas.
  • PNETs are classified as either functioning or non-functioning based on their ability to produce hormones.
  • Diagnosis of PNETs typically involves imaging studies such as CT or MRI, as well as biopsy or blood tests to measure hormone levels.
  • Treatment options for PNETs may include surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy, depending on the size, location, and type of tumor.

 

Insulinoma:

 

  • The investigation of choice for insulinoma 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.
  • Medical management:
    • Octreotide
  • Surgical management - Enucleation

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 13 to 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) is a double-stranded DNA virus that is primarily acquired in childhood and causes chickenpox. The virus is transmitted through direct contact with an infected individual. Nonimmune pregnant women who come into close contact with a patient with chickenpox are at risk of contracting the infection.

 

If a pregnant woman contracts chickenpox, particularly early in pregnancy, there is a risk of congenital varicella syndrome in the fetus. The highest risk period for the development of congenital varicella syndrome is between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Congenital varicella syndrome includes the following features:

 

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

 

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active VZV infection just before or during delivery (less than 5 days before and up to 2 days after delivery), there is a significant risk of disseminated disease and CNS involvement in the neonate, with a mortality rate of approximately 30%. In such cases, administration of VZIG (Varicella-Zoster Immune Globulin) is recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest risk period for the development of congenital varicella syndrome in a fetus is when the mother is infected with Varicella Zoster Virus between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 3085

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor more than 4 cm

 

While a tumor size larger than 4 cm is indicative of a relatively large tumor, it alone does not define locally advanced breast cancer. Locally advanced breast cancer typically involves not only tumor size but also the extent of its spread to nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inflammatory breast cancer: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive subtype of breast cancer characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth in the breast. It is considered an advanced stage of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Chest wall involvement: Locally advanced breast cancer is often defined by its involvement of the chest wall. This means that the cancer has spread beyond the breast tissue and may affect the underlying muscles and structures of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Skin involvement: Skin involvement, such as changes in the appearance of the skin over the breast like peau’d orange or ulceration, can be a feature of locally advanced breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor more than 5 cm, not 4 is classified as LABC.

 

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes: (Mnemonic – CUBE N2)

 

C - Chest wall invasion

 

U - Ulceration of skin

 

B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)

 

E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma

 

N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

choices.text: Made of amino acids and sugars

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about proteoglycans?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Holds less water

 

Proteoglycans are widely distributed complex molecules having glycosaminoglycans (GAG) and proteins. The GAGs containing repeating disaccharide units are covalently bound to the peptide chain to form proteoglycans. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Chondroitin sulfate It is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate → beta-1, 4 and so on. It is a glycosaminoglycan bound to a protein; hence it is a proteoglycan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carries Negative Charge: Proteoglycans carry negative charges due to the presence of sulfate and carboxyl groups on the GAG chains. These negatively charged groups attract positively charged ions and water molecules.

 

Option B. Chondroitin Sulfate is a Proteoglycan: Chondroitin sulfate is a type of GAG that, when attached to a core protein, forms a proteoglycan. It is widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, and skin.

 

Option C. Made of Amino Acids and Sugars: Proteoglycans are made up of a protein core (composed of amino acids) and one or more GAG chains (composed of sugars).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteoglycans are complex molecules made of amino acids and sugars, carrying negative charges and holding a significant amount of water due to their hydrophilic nature. Chondroitin sulfate, a type of GAG, forms proteoglycans when bound to a protein.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stomach

 

The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach.

 

 

The diagram shows the anterior relation of kidney:

 

 

The anterior relations of the left kidney involve various structures, including the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spleen: The spleen is typically located more to the left side of the abdomen, and it is not a direct anterior relation of the left kidney. However, there may be some variability in the position of the spleen, and in some individuals, a small part of the spleen might be located anterior to the left kidney.

 

Option C. 2nd part of duodenum: The second part of the duodenum runs horizontally and is situated anterior to the right kidney, it has no relation to the left kidney. This part of the duodenum is part of the foregut and is involved in the digestion and absorption of nutrients.

 

Option D. Pancreas: Pancreas in general is related to the left kidney but below the level of relation with stomach. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach is located anterior to the left kidney. The part of the stomach that lies in close proximity to the left kidney is the lesser curvature, specifically the anterior aspect of the stomach. The left kidney is situated posterior to this portion of the stomach.

questions.text: A community with a population of 20,000 documented 456 births in a year, of which 56 were stillbirths. The total number of deaths in the community for that year was 247, including 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and 34 additional deaths after 28 days but before completing the first year of life. What is the infant mortality rate (IMR) for this community? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 225

 

 

In the given question, out of total 456 births, 56 were dead born. 

 

Therefore, the number of live births= 456-56 = 400.

 

In the same year, it is given that the number of deaths before 28 days is 56, and the number of deaths after 28 days but before 1 year is 34.

 

Hence, the total number of deaths of children < 1 year is 56 + 34 = 90

 

IMR = (90x1000)/400 = 900/4 = 225

 

Hence, the IMR is 225 per 1000 live births.

 

INFANT MORTALITY RATE

 

  • It is the number of deaths per 1000 live births of children under one year of age. It is the most sensitive indicator of availability and utilization of health care services in a country. Is most important indicator of health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of MCH services in general. 
  • IMR is among ‘the best predictors of state failure’
  • It is a rate.
  • IMR of India (2023): 26.6 per 1000 live births; 
  • IMR of India - 35 per 1000 live births (NFHS-5 2019-21,); 28 per 1000 Live births (SRS, May 2022)
  • Is the second best indicator of socio-economic development of a country: Ultimate solution for lowering IMR lies in socio-economic development [Best indicator is U5MR]

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births.
  • This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.

 

NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‘single best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being’ (even better than IMR)

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.text: To accurately calculate the perinatal mortality rate, which of the following should specifically be considered as part of the numerator? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g 

 

Perinatal Mortality Rate (PNMR)

 

  • It includes both late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.

 

 

  • Perinatal period is from 28 weeks period of gestation to 7th completed days of life (But the WHO definition of perinatal period is from 22 completed weeks gestation to 7th completed days of life).
  • PNMR is a major marker to assess the quality of health care delivery; PNMR is a” Yardstick of Obstetric and Pediatric care before and around the time of birth”
  • P List (ICD 10): 100 causes of perinatal mortality and morbidity
  • PNMR of India (2022) - 18 per 1000 LB (SRS, September 2022)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perinatal mortality rate includes late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths, focusing on the period from 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
The assertion is correct statement, but the Reason is an incorrect statement.
The assertion is a incorrect statement, but the Reason is a correct statement.

questions.text:
Assertion: A patient comatose due to stroke in the past few hours should be intubated.

 

Reason: Following a stroke, there are high chances of a patient having sleep apnea.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The assertion is correct statement, but the Reason is an incorrect statement.

 

A patient who is comatose due to a recent stroke should indeed be intubated due to the increased risk of aspiration pneumonia. Stroke can impair swallowing reflexes and gag reflexes, which heightens the risk of aspiration and subsequent respiratory complications. This need for intubation is directly related to the prevention of aspiration, not to sleep apnea.

 

The Reason provided in the statement is incorrect because, although sleep apnea can occur in some stroke patients, it is not a common acute complication requiring immediate intervention. The primary concern in an unconscious stroke patient is the risk of aspiration, not sleep apnea. Thus, the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of comatose stroke patients, intubation is indicated primarily to prevent aspiration pneumonia due to compromised protective reflexes, not due to concerns about sleep apnea.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Divalent metal transporter 1

 

DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.

 

Luminal nonheme iron is mostly in the Fe [3] + (ferric state and is reduced to Fe [2] + (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases, such as b cytochromes and STEAP3. Fe [2] + iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

Fe [2] + iron destined for the circulation, is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin. This process is coupled to the oxidation of Fe [2] + iron to Fe [3] + iron, which is carried out by the iron oxidases hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin: Ferroportin is not involved in the initial transport of iron into the enterocyte. Instead, it is responsible for exporting iron from the enterocyte into the bloodstream. Ferroportin also works in tandem with hephaestin to ensure that Fe²⁺ iron is oxidized to Fe³⁺ before being released into circulation.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 2: There is no known transporter named "Divalent metal transporter 2" involved in iron absorption or transport within enterocytes. This option is incorrect and may be a distractor or incorrect reference.

 

Option D. Haptocorrin: Haptocorrin is a protein that binds vitamin B12 (cobalamin) in the stomach, protecting it from degradation. It is not involved in iron transport or metabolism, making this option incorrect in the context of iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the transport of Fe²⁺ iron across the apical membrane of enterocytes, facilitating iron absorption in the gut.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1230

questions.text: Drug with mechanism of action are given in two columns. Which of the following is the correct match?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-E

 

The correct matches between the drugs and their mechanisms of action are as follows:

  1. Omalizumab - Anti-IgE (1-C)
    • Indication: Omalizumab is used in the treatment of bronchial asthma. It works by binding to IgE, which plays a key role in allergic reactions.
  2. Itolizumab - Anti-CD 6 (2-A)
    • Indication: Itolizumab is a new drug used for psoriasis. It targets CD6, a molecule involved in T-cell activation.
  3. Daclizumab - Anti-CD 25 (3-B)
    • Indication: Daclizumab acts as an IL-2 receptor antagonist by binding to CD25, which is part of the IL-2 receptor. It is used as an immunosuppressant.
  4. Belimumab - Anti-B lymphocyte stimulator (BlyS) (4-E)
    • Indication: Belimumab is used for the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It inhibits B-lymphocyte stimulator, which is involved in the survival of B cells.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Reference: KDT 8TH/251-52,943

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Binding of ATP

 

Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

 

 

Energy for movement of myosin head (power stroke) is obtained by breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) into adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and inorganic phosphate (Pi). Head of myosin has a site for ATP and itself can act as the enzyme ATPase and catalyse the breakdown of ATP.

 

Even before the onset of contraction, an ATP molecule binds with myosin head.

When tropomyosin moves to expose the active sites, the head is attached to the active site. Now ATPase cleaves ATP into ADP and Pi, which remains in head itself. The energy released during this process is utilized for contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum: Incorrect. The entry of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum helps in muscle relaxation but does not directly cause the detachment of the myosin head from actin.

 

Option C. Change in troponin C configuration: Incorrect. The change in troponin C configuration exposes the active sites on actin for myosin binding but does not cause detachment.

 

Option D. Release of ADP and Pi: Incorrect. The release of ADP and Pi occurs after the power stroke but does not cause the detachment of the myosin head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of the myosin head from actin is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which is a critical step in the muscle contraction and relaxation cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tryptophan

 

The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4). It is seen in patients with pellagra, as a result of niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency or tryptophan deficiency.

 

Deficiency of niacin leads to the clinical condition called pellagra. Pellagra is an Italian word, meaning “rough skin”. Pellagra is caused by the deficiency of Tryptophan as well as Niacin. Pellagra is seen more in women; this may be because tryptophan metabolism is inhibited by estrogen metabolites.

 

The symptoms of pellagra are (3 Ds):

 

  1. Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs, especially in the feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal necklace. The dermatitis is precipitated by exposure to sunlight
  2. Diarrhea: The diarrhea may be mild or severe with blood and mucus. This may lead to weight loss. Nausea and vomiting may also be present.
  3. Dementia: It is frequently seen in chronic cases.

 

Delirium is common in acute Pellagra. Irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory are more common in mild cases. Ataxia, and spasticity are also seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option.  A. Phenylalanine, C. Glutamine: and D. Arginine: Deficiency of these amino acids are not associated with pellagra.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pellagra can occur due to:

 

  • ﻿﻿Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency
  • ﻿﻿Tryptophan deficiency: Niacin is synthetised from tryptophan
  • Deficient synthesis: Kynureninase, an important enzyme in the pathway of tryptophan, is pyridoxal phosphate dependent. So, conversion of tryptophan to niacin is not possible in pyridoxal deficiency.
  • Isoniazid (INH): It is an anti-tubercular drug, which inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation. Hence, there is block in conversion of tryptophan to NAD.
  • Hartnup disease: Tryptophan absorption from intestine is defective in this congenital disease. Moreover, tryptophan is excreted in urine in large quantities. This leads to lack of tryptophan and consequently deficiency of nicotinamide.
  • Carcinoid syndrome: The tumor utilizes major portion of available tryptophan for synthesis of serotonin; so, tryptophan is unavailable.

choices.text: All are true
A, B and C only
A, C, and E only
A, B, D and E

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding foscarnet are True?

 

  1. It is used for resistant CMV infections
  2. Renal toxicity is seen
  3. It is activated by viral thymidine kinase
  4. Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required
  5. It can cause genital ulceration
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A, B, D and E

 

Foscarnet is an antiviral medication used primarily for the treatment of cytomegalovirus (CMV) and other herpesvirus infections, particularly when the viruses are resistant to other treatments like ganciclovir and acyclovir.

 

Statements:

 

A. It is used for resistant CMV infections

 

This is true. Foscarnet is effective against CMV, including strains that are resistant to ganciclovir.

 

B. Renal toxicity is seen

 

This is true. Renal toxicity is a significant adverse effect of foscarnet, which can lead to acute renal failure and other renal complications.

 

D. Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required

 

This is true. Due to its potential to cause electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypocalcemia, regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is necessary during foscarnet therapy.

 

E. It can cause genital ulceration

 

This is true. Genital ulceration is one of the potential side effects of foscarnet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. It is activated by viral thymidine kinase: This is false. Foscarnet does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase. Unlike acyclovir and ganciclovir, foscarnet directly inhibits viral DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase, and HIV reverse transcriptase without needing to be phosphorylated by viral enzymes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Drug of choice for herpes simplex virus and varicella zoster virus infection is acyclovir.
  • Drug of choice for cytomegalovirus is ganciclovir.
  • Both acyclovir and ganciclovir are pro-drugs and require activation by kinases.

 

FOSCARNET

 

  • It is a simple straight chain phosphonate.
  • It does not require activation by kinases.
  • It is active against H. simplex (including strains resistant to acyclovir), CMV (including ganciclovir-resistant ones) and other herpes group viruses.
  • Oral absorption is poor. Its t½ is 4–8 hours, and it is not metabolized by liver.
  • Toxicity of foscarnet is high. It damages kidney and produces a renal diabetes like condition; acute renal failure can also occur. Anemia, phlebitis, tremors, convulsions, genital ulceration and other neurological as well as constitutional symptoms due to hypocalcemia are frequent.
  • It is administered by i.v. infusion
     

Reference: KDT 8th/852, 853

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

Inhalational of anthrax spores (<5 microns) are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, carried to local mediastinal lymph nodes releasing toxins causing hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

It is category A bioterrorism agent along with plague, botulism

 

Treatment recommended with IV antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin+Clindamycin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical pneumonia occurs in Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Legionella pneumonia causing interstitial infiltrates

 

Option B. Lung abscess is seen as complication of infection with anaerobes, complication of pneumonia, atypical organisms like burkholderia, Infective endocarditis with septic embolism

 

Option D. Bronchopneumonia occurs due to pneumococcus, H.influenza etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the hallmark presentation of inhalational anthrax, indicating a severe systemic infection that requires immediate medical attention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Awareness of this presentation is crucial, particularly in contexts involving potential exposure to anthrax spores, such as bioterrorism.

questions.text: In a 25-year-old man who visited a primary health center with complaints as shown in the image below, 5 days after engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse. The patient experienced painful ulcers upon palpation, and there was suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy on the right side. Additionally, the patient has no history of drug allergy. What specific kit will be used for managing this sexually transmitted disease? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kit 3/white

 

The clinical image and findings presented above are consistent with chancroid, a sexually transmitted disease.

 

Chancroid:

 

  • The causative agent responsible for chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • The incubation period typically ranges from 3 to 10 days.
  • It is characterized by the presence of painful and deep ulcers, along with tender lymphadenopathy. The recommended kit for managing this condition is Kit 3/White.
  • Initially, a painful papule appears, which later transforms into a painful, non-indurated ulcer with undermined edges, often accompanied by central necrosis.
  • Autoinoculation may lead to the presence of "kissing ulcers."
  • The disease is also associated with painful lymphadenopathy, which can progress to form suppurating sinuses and buboes.
  • When the patient presents with both genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo), it is referred to as concomitant genital ulcer as shown below.

 

Chancroid showing Concomitant genital ulcer: Small soft ulcer on the internal surface of the prepuce with painful, fluctuant inguinal adenitis (bubo).

 

NACO KIT 3 / White color KIT

 

Kit 3/white consists of:

 

  1. Tablet Azithromycin 1gm single dose, which is used for the treatment of chancroid.
  2. Injection Benzathine Penicillin 2.4 Million IU deep IM stat, which is used for syphilis.

 

 

  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen associated with Chancroid, but absent in LGV.
  • First line treatment for Chancroid is azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose or ceftriaxone 250 mg IM as a single dose.

 

The second-line options for chancroid are as follows:

 

  • Ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice a day for 3 days (OR)
  • Erythromycin base 500 mg orally four times a day for 7 days

 

Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:

 

 

Other KITs:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When managing a patient presenting with painful genital ulcers and suppurative lymphadenopathy (Bubo), the primary consideration is to treat for chancroid which is a STI, typically with a kit containing appropriate antibiotics.

 

Kit 3/white consists of:

 

  1. Tablet Azithromycin, which is used for the treatment of chancroid.
  2. Injection Benzathine Penicillin, which is used for syphilis.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition, Chapter 30 Page no 30.21

questions.text: All of the following can cause miosis except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Belladonna

 

Belladonna is plant (Atropa belladonna) from which atropine (Anticholinergic drug) is obtained. It causes mydriasis not miosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphates: Organophosphates cause miosis by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, which increases acetylcholine levels, resulting in overstimulation of muscarinic receptors.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine induces miosis by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system through opioid receptors, leading to pupil constriction.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug that causes miosis by directly activating muscarinic receptors in the eye.

 

Educational objective:

 

Miosis or pin point pupil is caused by:-

 

  • Organophosphate poisoning
  • Opioids like morphine
  • Phenol poisoning
  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Cholinergic drugs like pilocarpine

 

Reference: KDT 8th/115,122,127,499

questions.text: Patient affected with acute hepatitis B infection has currently come for follow up. Identify the serological marker marked in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc Ab

 

Anti Hbc Ab are produced against Hepatitis B infection. IgM is produced early and IgG later. Production of antibodies(A) is seen to correspond to gradual reduction of surface, envelop antigens.

 

 

Person recovering from acute infection may have negative anti HbS levels with low HbsAg levels. This is called window period where there is a lag between development of antiHbS and HbsAg levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-HBe Ab: These antibodies against the hepatitis B e antigen generally signify lower levels of viral replication. They are not represented at the marked point in the graph.

 

Option C. Anti-HBs Ab: These antibodies indicate recovery and immunity and typically appear after the disappearance of HBsAg, which occurs later than the timeframe shown for the marked serological marker.

 

Option D. HBsAg: This is the earliest detectable viral antigen to appear in the blood following infection but declines as Anti-HBc Ab and later Anti-HBs appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBc antibodies are crucial in diagnosing hepatitis B infection, as they appear early after exposure and persist throughout the infection. They are typically seen during the "window period" when HBsAg starts to wane and before Anti-HBs becomes detectable, indicating the body's initial immune response to the infection.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Hepatology/Viral hepatitis/ chap 339/

choices.text: Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax
Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy
Treatment of severe falciparum malaria
Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following is clinical use of tafenoquine? (AIIMS Nov 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax

 

Radical cure – Several patients of P. vivax malaria relapse due to persistence of exo-erythrocytic stage. Drugs which attack this stage (hypnozooites) given together with a clinical curative achieve total eradication of the parasite from the patient's body.

 

Drug of choice for radical cure of vivax and ovale malaria is:

 

  • Primaquine 15 mg daily for 14 days
  • Tafenoquine is a new long-acting exo-erythrocytic schizontocidal drug. It has been developed as a single dose radical cure for vivax malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy: Tafenoquine is not recommended for malaria prophylaxis in pregnancy due to its potential for causing hemolysis in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Pregnant women are typically advised to use other antimalarial drugs for prophylaxis.

 

Option C. Treatment of severe falciparum malaria: The treatment of severe falciparum malaria typically involves intravenous administration of drugs like artesunate or quinine, rather than tafenoquine. Tafenoquine is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years: Tafenoquine is not recommended for use in children under 2 years of age. The safety and efficacy of tafenoquine in this age group have not been established, and alternative antimalarial therapies are preferred for young children.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax malaria due to its long-acting effects against the exo-erythrocytic stage of the parasite, helping to prevent relapses.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 878

questions.text: All of the following can be used to decreased intraocular pressure in glaucoma except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dexamethasone

 

Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid. Corticosteroids are contraindicated in glaucoma because they can lead to an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). This rise in IOP can exacerbate glaucoma and potentially cause further damage to the optic nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for acute congestive glaucoma when administered intravenously. It decreases IOP by creating an osmotic gradient, which helps to draw fluid out of the eye, thereby reducing congestion.

 

Option B. Methazolamide: Methazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It decreases the production of aqueous humor in the eye, which in turn reduces intraocular pressure. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are effective in managing glaucoma.

 

Option C. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. Alpha-2 agonists are commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma.

  

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - Dexamethasone is contraindicated in glaucoma

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 318, 167, 170

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Babesia

 

Babesia is not an intracellular parasite of hepatocytes. It is an intra-erythrocytic parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Toxoplasma gondii can infect hepatocytes as part of its lifecycle.

 

Option B. Plasmodium: The liver stage (hepatic schizogony) of Plasmodium involves hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Leishmania species infect macrophages, which can reside in the liver, leading to intracellular infection in hepatocytes indirectly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obligate intracellular parasites-

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi
  • Leishmania spp.
  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Babesia spp. -> RBC
  • Toxoplasma gondii
  • Microsporidia

questions.text: Which of the following actions leads to an increase in acetylcholine (ACh) release from the presynaptic neuron?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium channel blocker

 

Potassium channel blockers increase acetylcholine (ACh) release from the presynaptic neuron. Blocking potassium channels prolongs depolarization of the neuron, which enhances the influx of calcium through voltage-gated calcium channels. This increased calcium entry then promotes greater ACh release at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Aminopyridines, which are potassium channel blockers, are used in the treatment of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome to improve muscle strength by increasing ACh release.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium channel blocker: Blocking sodium channels would reduce neuronal depolarization, thus decreasing calcium entry and subsequently reducing ACh release.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blocker: Blocking calcium channels would directly prevent calcium influx, leading to a decrease in ACh release from the presynaptic neuron.

 

Option D. Chlorine channel blocker: Chlorine (chloride) channels do not directly affect ACh release. Chloride ions typically stabilize the membrane potential, so blocking them would not specifically increase ACh release.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Potassium channel blockers enhance acetylcholine release by prolonging neuronal depolarization and increasing calcium influx at the presynaptic terminal.

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endocardial cushions

 

Explanation:

 

The interventricular septum's membranous portion is the indicated structure. It comes from the endocardial cushions.

 

 

  • Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude in the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions.
    • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells.
    • The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Septum primum: The septum primum is involved in the development of the atrial septum, not the interventricular septum. It forms a temporary structure in the embryonic heart that helps separate the atria.

 

Option C. Left venous valve: The left venous valve is not directly involved in the formation of the interventricular septum. It is a structure found within the embryonic heart that helps direct oxygenated blood from the left atrium into the left ventricle.

 

Option D. Bulbous venosus: The bulbous venosus is an embryonic structure that contributes to the formation of the smooth part of the right ventricle. It is not associated with the development of the interventricular septum.

 

 

Cardiac abnormalities, such as ASs, VSDs, and anomalies affecting the major arteries, can be caused by errors in the creation of the endocardial cushion (transposition of the great vessels, common truncus arterious, and tetralogy of Fallot).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endocardial cushions contribute to the formation of:

 

  1. Atrial septa
  2. Ventricular septa (membranous portion)
  3. Atrioventricular canals
  4. Atrioventricular valves

 

The membranous portion of the interventricular septum develops from the endocardial cushions.

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediately

 

Immediate dilated fundus examination is recommended for individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, as early detection of diabetic retinopathy is crucial for preventing vision loss. Screening at diagnosis is essential because diabetic retinopathy can be asymptomatic in its early stages, yet still pose a risk of significant damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Before his 50th birthday: While this is within five years of diagnosis, immediate examination is preferred for immediate intervention and management.

 

Option C. After his 50th birthday: Delaying the examination could lead to unnoticed progression of diabetic retinopathy and potentially irreversible damage.

 

Option D. When he complains of decrease in vision: Waiting for symptoms such as decreased vision can result in delayed diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy, at which point some damage may be irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with 2-3 hypopigmented, slightly raised patches on his forearm with reduced sensation for 4 months. He is diagnosed with paucibacillary leprosy. What is the recommended treatment regimen? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 drug therapy for 6 months

 

  • The treatment regimen for paucibacillary leprosy involves a 6-month course of drug therapy with 2 drugs (Dapsone, Rifampicin).
  • Diagnosis of leprosy under NLEP: It is currently based on clinical grounds (revised case definition) - 

 

Paucibacillary (PB) case: A case of leprosy with 1 to 5 skin lesions, without demonstrated presence of bacilli in a skin smear;

 

Multibacillary (MB) case: A case of leprosy with more than five skin lesions; or with nerve involvement (pure neuritis, or any number of skin lesions and neuritis); or with the demonstrated presence of bacilli in a slit-skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

MDT blister pack Colour

 

PBL adult - Green color

 

MBL adult - Red color

 

PBL child - Blue color

 

MBL child - Yellow colour

questions.text:
Which of the following is True regarding drugs used for viral infections?

 

  1. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir
  2. Ombitasvir is inhibitor of proteins synthesis
  3. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata
  4. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C
  5. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu
questions.solution:
Ans. A. C, D and E

 

C. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata: This statement is true. Imiquimod is an immunomodulator used for the treatment of various viral warts, including condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

 

D. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C: This statement is true. Simprevir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HCV, which works by inhibiting the NS3/4A protease enzyme necessary for viral replication.

 

E. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu: This statement is true. Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication effective against influenza A (including H5N1 and H1N1, commonly known as swine flu) and influenza B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir: This statement is false. Ribavirin, when used for the treatment of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV), must be combined with injectable interferons, which have significant adverse effects. Sofosbuvir, a newer oral drug that inhibits the NS5B RNA polymerase, is preferred over ribavirin due to its better efficacy and fewer side effects.

 

Option B. Ombitasvir is an inhibitor of protein synthesis: This statement is false. Ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, meaning it acts by inhibiting viral RNA replication and assembly of the hepatitis C virus (HCV), not protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sofosbuvir is preferred over ribavirin for HCV treatment due to better efficacy, ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, imiquimod is used for condyloma acuminata, simprevir inhibits HCV protease, and oseltamivir is used for swine flu.

 

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 853,856,858

questions.text: The following device shown attached to the baby is used in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Measure central cyanosis.

 

The device shown in the image is a pulse oximeter. A pulse oximeter is commonly used to measure the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of the blood and monitor heart rate. While it is useful in many clinical settings, including neonatal care, it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

 

Cyanosis is a clinical sign that appears when there is at least 5 g/dL of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood. A pulse oximeter measures oxygen saturation but does not directly assess the color changes in the skin or mucous membranes, which are crucial for identifying cyanosis. Moreover, in conditions like severe anemia, a patient might have a low oxygen saturation without appearing cyanosed.

 

However, measuring central cyanosis requires clinical observation and is not reliably detected by a pulse oximeter. Therefore, a pulse oximeter is not used to measure central cyanosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Uses of a Pulse Oximeter:

 

Option A. In CPR: Pulse oximeters are used to monitor oxygenation and the effectiveness of chest compressions and ventilation during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

 

Option B. To know about apnea: Pulse oximeters can indicate apnea by detecting bradycardia and desaturation episodes.

 

Option C. In neonatal resuscitation: Pulse oximeters are vital for assessing the newborn's oxygenation status during resuscitation and adjusting oxygen therapy as needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pulse oximeter is useful in various neonatal and resuscitation settings to monitor oxygen saturation and heart rate, but it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BTK

 

BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency).

 

Other Options:

 

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. In this condition, the following genes are involved:

 

Option B. JAK3: Mutations in the JAK3 gene are associated with an autosomal recessive form of SCID. JAK3 is essential for the signaling pathways of multiple cytokine receptors, including IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-15, and IL-21, which are crucial for lymphocyte development and function.

 

Option C.  RAG1: The RAG1 gene, along with RAG2, is crucial for V(D)J recombination, which is necessary for the generation of diverse antigen receptors on B cells and T cells. Mutations in RAG1 can lead to SCID due to the inability to produce functional B and T cells.

 

Option D. IL-7Ra: The IL-7 receptor alpha chain (IL-7Ra) is important for T-cell development. Mutations in IL-7Ra can lead to a T- B+ NK+ form of SCID, where T cells are absent or non-functional, but B cells and natural killer cells are present.

 

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including:

 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is caused by mutations in several different genes

 

  • JAK3
  • RAG1
  • IL-7Ra

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 438-439

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is found to have a unilateral undescended testis on the right side during a routine physical exam. A diagnostic laparoscopy is performed, which reveals blind-ending testicular vessels and vas deferens on the right side. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nothing to be done

 

Blind-ending vas deferens and testicular vessels imply anorchism or testicular agenesis. In such cases, no further exploration is required.

 

When diagnostic laparoscopy reveals blind-ending testicular vessels, it indicates the absence or nonviable nature of the testis. In such cases, there is no surgical intervention required because there is no viable testis to locate or bring down. The appropriate management approach is to monitor the patient and provide counseling regarding the absence of the testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inguinal exploration: Inguinal exploration involves surgical exploration of the inguinal canal to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the diagnostic laparoscopy has already revealed blind-ending testicular vessels on the right side. This finding indicates that the testis is absent or nonviable, and no further surgical exploration is needed.

 

Option B. Abdominal exploration: Abdominal exploration is typically performed when an undescended testis is suspected to be located within the abdominal cavity. However, in this case, the laparoscopy has confirmed the absence of a viable testis on the right side.

 

Option C. Scrotal exploration: Scrotal exploration involves surgical exploration of the scrotum to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the laparoscopy findings have already established the absence of a viable testis on the right side, making scrotal exploration unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A unilateral undescended testis refers to a condition in which only one of the testes has not descended into the scrotum, while the other testis has descended normally. This condition is relatively common in male infants and can occur on either the right or left side.

 

Here are some key points about unilateral undescended testis:

 

  1. Incidence: It is one of the most common congenital anomalies in male infants, with the majority of cases involving the left testis.
  2. Diagnosis: Unilateral undescended testis is typically diagnosed during a physical examination, such as a routine well-baby check or pediatric evaluation.
  3. Management: The management of unilateral undescended testis may vary based on the age of the child and the specific circumstances. In many cases, the testis will descend into the scrotum on its own within the first few months of life. If the testis has not descended by the age of 6 months, treatment options may include hormone therapy to stimulate descent or surgical intervention (orchidopexy) to bring the testis down into the scrotum.
  4. Importance of Treatment: The goal of treatment is to ensure that the undescended testis is properly positioned in the scrotum. This is important for several reasons, including the potential impact on fertility and the increased risk of testicular cancer in undescended testes if left untreated.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Among the options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

questions.text: A patient presents with flu-like symptoms after a camping trip and multiple insect bites. You suspect a vector-borne illness. Which pathogen is likely if the vector is a Trombiculid mite? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • Above given image depicts Trombiculid mite, which transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi. It causes scrub typhus disease in humans.

 

 

  • Life cycle of Trombiculid mite with transovarial transmission

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Kyasanur forest disease virus: Kyasanur forest disease virus is transmitted by hard tick

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is an Arbovirus transmitted by Sand fly (Phlebotomus)

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma phagocytophilia: Anaplasma phagocytophilia (formerly Ehrlichia phagocytophilum) is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes an acute febrile illness known as anaplasmosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Orientia tsutsugamushi, transmitted by Trombiculid mites, causes scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes, recently diagnosed with end-stage renal disease (stage 5) and on hemodialysis, seeks dietary advice. Which of the following characterizes the ideal renal feed for him? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low volume, high calories

 

  • An ideal diet for a patient with end-stage renal disease should consist of low volume but high calorie intake. The patient's dietary choices can significantly impact the advancement of kidney disease and its associated complications. Opting for a diet that is low in volume is recommended to prevent:
    • Sodium and volume overload
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hyperphosphatemia
    • Accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradation
  • Opting for a high-calorie diet is recommended for the potential malnutrition and wasting risks observed in individuals with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High volume, low calories: This could lead to volume overload and insufficient caloric intake.

 

Option C. High volume, high calories: High volume can cause fluid overload issues.

 

Option D. Low volume, low calories: Insufficient calories can exacerbate malnutrition and wasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An ideal diet for patients with end-stage renal disease should be low in volume to manage fluid balance and high in calories to prevent malnutrition and wasting.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
The Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.
Both Assertion and Reason are false.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Malathion is used as an ultra-low volume fogger during epidemics.


Reason (R): Ultra-low volume foggers have no residual effects.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.

 

Malathion is indeed used as an ultra-low volume (ULV) fogger during epidemics, particularly for vector control, as it helps control mosquito populations effectively. However, the statement in the Reason is incorrect. Ultra-low volume foggers, including Malathion, can leave residual effects. Malathion has residual action that lasts up to approximately 3 months, which makes it useful in epidemic control for an extended period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malathion is preferred as an ultra-low volume fogger due to its low toxicity among organophosphates, but it does have residual effects lasting up to 3 months.

questions.text: A 28-year-old public health nurse is attending a seminar on primary prevention strategies. She needs to identify interventions that fall under specific protection, a subset of primary prevention. Which of the following interventions does NOT come under the primary level of prevention for specific protection? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hand washing

 

  • Specific protection mode of disease prevention: Is a Primary level of disease prevention (applied when risk factors are present in environment but disease has not yet taken place).
  • Risk factors are already present but disease is prevented from occurring by using a specific modality. Ex - Vaccines & Vit A supplementation under NIS, chemoprophylaxis, IFA supplementation, contraception, ITN, etc
  • Handwashing fall within the category of primary prevention as a Health Promotion measure, not specific protection, as it is not a protective measures targeted at any particular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningitis prophylaxis in exposed contacts/relatives: This is a form of specific protection, aimed at preventing the onset of meningitis in those exposed to the infection.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccination is a classic example of specific protection, preventing the occurrence of specific diseases.

 

Option D. Adding iron to wheat flour: This is a specific protection measure to prevent iron deficiency anemia in the population by fortifying commonly consumed food products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hand washing is a health promotion measure and does not fall under specific protection in primary prevention strategies.
  • Note - Chinese Medicine is the Pioneer in concept of ‘Specific protection by vaccine’

questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated for: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CAD Prophylaxis

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not recommended for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD). Although there was some belief in the past that HRT might provide cardiovascular benefits, extensive research has shown that HRT does not prevent CAD and may, in fact, increase the risk of certain cardiovascular events in some women.

 

HRT is primarily indicated for the management of symptoms associated with menopause and for certain therapeutic and prophylactic uses:

 

Therapeutic Indications:

 

  • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Premature ovarian failure
  • Hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms)
  • Vaginal dryness

 

Prophylactic Indications:

 

  • Prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women

 

Risks of HRT:

 

  • Increased risk of endometrial cancer (particularly with unopposed estrogen in women with an intact uterus)
  • Increased risk of breast cancer
  • Increased risk of ovarian cancer
  • Increased risk of thromboembolism
  • Possible adverse effects on lipid profiles
  • Increased risk of gallstones and liver dysfunction

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot flashes: HRT is widely used to manage hot flashes and other vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause. It is one of the most effective treatments for these symptoms.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis: HRT is used prophylactically to prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women by maintaining bone density and reducing the risk of fractures.

 

Option D. Premature menopause: Women experiencing premature menopause or premature ovarian failure can benefit from HRT to manage symptoms and reduce the long-term risks associated with early loss of estrogen, including osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not indicated for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 61,62
