choices.text: Glutamine replaced by asparagine
Glutamine replaced by alanine
Glutamine replaced by glutamate
Glutamine replaced by arginine

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamine replaced by asparagine

 

Amino acid replacement is a change from one amino acid to a different amino acid in a protein due to point mutation in the corresponding DNA sequence. It is caused by nonsynonymous missense mutation which changes the codon sequence to code other amino acid instead of the original.

 

Usually, amino acids are thus classified into two types:

 

  1. Conservative replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another that has similar properties. This type of replacement is expected to rarely result in dysfunction in the corresponding protein.

For example, leucine and isoleucine are both aliphatic, branched hydrophobes. Similarly, aspartic acid and glutamic acid are both small, negatively charged residues.

 

  1. Radical replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another with different properties. This can lead to changes in protein structure or function, which can cause potentially lead to changes in phenotype, sometimes pathogenic.

 

Example - Sickle cell anemia, due to a mutation in beta globin where at position 6 glutamic acid (negatively charged) is exchanged with valine (not charged).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glutamine replaced by alanine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while alanine is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid. This radical replacement could affect the protein's structure or function.

 

Option C. Glutamine replaced by glutamate: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while glutamate is a polar, negatively charged amino acid. Although they are similar in size, the difference in charge makes this a radical replacement, potentially affecting protein function.

 

Option D. Glutamine replaced by arginine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while arginine is a polar, positively charged amino acid. This radical replacement could significantly alter the protein's structure or function.

 

Educational Objective

 

Conservative replacements, such as replacing glutamine with asparagine, typically do not affect the protein's function because the substituted amino acids have similar properties. Radical replacements, involving amino acids with different properties, are more likely to impact protein function.

questions.text: Which causative agent is responsible for the 4-year-old boy's condition, characterized by painful mouth sores, a rash on the hands, and fever as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackievirus

 

The above scenario is suggestive of hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16).CV‐A6 and EV71 are also other important causative organisms.

 

  • Age group commonly affected: Children.
  • Spread: Droplets / fecal contamination.
  • Incubation period: 7 days.
  • Clinical features: In children, the onset is with a low‐grade fever, sore throat and malaise but in adults, a painful stomatitis is an early feature. 
    • Blisters in the mouth soon break down to superficial ulcers.
    • Children are more likely than adults to develop flaccid greyish 2–5 mm oval vesicles on the palms and slightly less frequently on the soles.
  • They fade after 2–3 days. Infection can be subclinical.
  • Only symptomatic treatment is given.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus:

 

  • Poxviruses cause diseases such as smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, which have very different clinical presentations from HFMD.
  • Smallpox, which has been eradicated, presented with a characteristic vesicular and pustular rash and high mortality.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by firm, painless, umbilicated papules, not the presentation seen in the images provided.

 

Option C. HHV-7 (Human Herpesvirus-7):

 

  • HHV-7 is associated with roseola, a viral infection characterized by a high fever and a rash.
  • HHV 7 is also associated with Pityriasis rosea.
  • However, it does not typically cause painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands.

 

Option D. Parvovirus: Parvovirus B19 can cause a condition called fifth disease, which may result in a rash on the face classically described as slapped cheek appearance as shown in the below image

 

 

but parvo virus not known for causing painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands. Additionally, fifth disease is more common in children between 5 and 15 years old, so it is less likely in a 4-year-old.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of fever, painful oral sores, and a vesicular rash on the hands and feet in a young child is characteristic of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease, which is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus.

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 25 Page no 25.81, chapter 117, Page no 117.6

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1591

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enhancer deletion

 

Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene. On the contrary, deletion of an enhancer would likely reduce the expression of the gene, potentially reducing its oncogenic potential, rather than increasing it.

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promoter insertion: Can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene by increasing gene transcription.

 

Option C. Gene amplification: Leads to an increased number of gene copies, enhancing gene product levels, and contributing to oncogenesis.

 

Option D. Point mutation: A common mechanism for converting proto-oncogenes to oncogenes by altering the protein product to make it constitutively active.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transformation of proto-oncogene (i.e., normal cell proliferation gene) to oncogenes (i.e., cancer cell proliferation gene) may occur by three mechanisms:

 

  1. Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription. 
  2. Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls.  Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22.
  3. Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region,  ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 549-551

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding investigation of malignant bone tumors? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Always done by transverse incision.
  2. Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  3. Sample should be taken before any radiological investigations.
  4. Sample should be taken from periphery and not from necrotic centre.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor. 

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone and the most frequent cause of pathologic fractures in children.
  • Bone cysts usually affect patients between 5 and 15 years of age and occur more often in boys than in girls (2:1).
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%. The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • It is more common in males than in females with a peak incidence in the second decade of life.
  • Although it may be present in almost any bone, the proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and  it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive.
    • A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve.
    • If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10–15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • Incidence is Males > Females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor.

questions.text: Identify the clinical diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plexiform neurofibromatosis

 

Plexiform neurofibroma is seen in patients with NF1 commonly in the craniomaxillofacial region. Malignant transformation to MPNST (Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor) occurs in 3-16% patients and is the cause of mortality.

 

The mass typically appears as a "bag of worms" due to the involvement of multiple nerve branches.

 

Treatment is mainly surgical resection of the tumor

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve palsy: This condition typically presents with asymmetrical facial movement and weakness but does not cause mass-like growths.

 

Option B. Masticator space abscess: Characterized by swelling and pain, usually due to an infection, which would not cause the extensive, benign proliferative growth seen in the image.

 

Option D. Fibrous dysplasia: While it can cause bone deformity and asymmetry, it does not manifest as a soft, extensive mass typically seen in neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plexiform neurofibromatosis should be suspected in patients with extensive, soft, non-tender, and irregularly contoured masses along nerve pathways, particularly in those known to have or suspected of having NF1. Surgical resection can be considered for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons, though complete removal is often challenging due to the nature of the growth

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RML consolidation

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray shown above indicates consolidation due to presence of opacities in the right middle lobe silhouetting the right heart border along with the history of fever, cough and hemoptysis.

 

Silhouette sign

 

 

  • When the markings of heart are not visible – silhouette sign positive – localized to middle lobe /lingula
  • When the markings of heart are visible – silhouette sign negative – localized to lower lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RLL consolidation: Typically presents with obscuration of the right hemidiaphragm on X-ray, not the heart border.

 

Option C. RUL consolidation: Would more commonly show opacities in the upper right lung without affecting the silhouette of the heart.

 

Option D. Pericardial effusion: Would generally show an enlarged cardiac silhouette ("water bottle" sign), which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective :

 

RML consolidation can be diagnosed when there is obscuration of the right heart border due to lung opacities in the middle lobe, accompanied by clinical symptoms of respiratory infection.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt without a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

questions.text: A patient presents with a large, deep wound and the healthcare provider decides to use a specific wound-healing procedure. What is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative pressure wound therapy

 

Negative pressure wound therapy, also known as vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy, involves the application of negative pressure to a wound using a sealed dressing connected to a vacuum pump.

 

  • This therapy helps in wound healing by several mechanisms: it removes excess fluid and infectious materials from the wound, improves blood flow to the area, reduces edema (swelling), and promotes the formation of granulation tissue.
  • It is often used for large, deep wounds, chronic wounds, and complex surgical wounds to accelerate the healing process.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

VAC therapy = vacuum assisted closure therapy

 

  1. Mechanism of action: VAC therapy involves the application of negative pressure (-125 mm of hg) to a wound to promote wound healing. The negative pressure removes excess fluid and promotes the formation of granulation tissue and new blood vessels.
  2. Indications: VAC therapy is commonly used for the management of complex wounds, such as diabetic foot ulcers, pressure ulcers, and surgical wounds. It can also be used to manage wounds with high risk of infection.
  3. Procedure: VAC therapy involves placing a foam dressing over the wound and covering it with an adhesive film. A tube is then inserted through the film and connected to a vacuum pump, which applies negative pressure to the wound. The pressure can be adjusted to provide the optimal level of tension for the specific wound.

questions.text: Stage the bedsore in the following image: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4

 

The image depicts a Stage 4 pressure ulcer (bedsore), which is characterized by deep tissue loss that exposes underlying structures such as muscle, bone, or supporting tissues. Stage 4 is the most severe form of pressure ulcer, often showing significant tissue necrosis, deep crater formation, and the possibility of undermining or tunneling under the skin.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stage 4 pressure ulcers are characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with visible muscle, bone, or supporting structures, making them the most severe and challenging to manage.

questions.text: Like all the opioids, tramadol acts as an analgesic drug by stimulating mu opioid receptors. Apart from this, the additional analgesic mechanism of tramadol is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serotonin and nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibition

 

Tramadol is an atypical opioid analgesic that not only acts by stimulating mu opioid receptors, like other opioids, but also has an additional mechanism of action. This dual mechanism contributes to its analgesic effect.

 

  • Mu Opioid Receptor Agonism: Tramadol binds to mu opioid receptors, which are part of the body's endogenous pain relief system. Activation of these receptors leads to pain relief.
  • Serotonin and Noradrenaline Reuptake Inhibition: Unlike typical opioids, tramadol also inhibits the reuptake of serotonin (5-HT) and noradrenaline (NA). This increases the levels of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, enhancing their action. This mechanism activates the monoaminergic descending inhibitory pathways in the spinal cord, which further contributes to pain relief.

 

Due to its unique mechanism, tramadol's analgesic action is only partially reversed by naloxone, an opioid antagonist, indicating that non-opioid mechanisms also play a significant role in its pain-relieving effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anticholinergic: Tramadol does not have anticholinergic properties. Anticholinergic drugs block the action of acetylcholine in the brain and are not related to the analgesic mechanism of tramadol.

 

Option C. Antihistaminic: Tramadol does not act as an antihistamine. Antihistamines are used primarily to treat allergic reactions and have no significant role in pain relief through histamine receptor antagonism.

 

Option D. Serotonin and dopamine reuptake inhibition: While tramadol does inhibit serotonin reuptake, it does not inhibit dopamine reuptake significantly. Its main additional mechanism of analgesia is through the inhibition of serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tramadol provides pain relief not only through mu opioid receptor agonism but also by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and noradrenaline, thereby activating the descending inhibitory pain pathways in the spinal cord.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/504

choices.text: Residual from barrel of gun
Gutter fracture of skull

questions.text: What is bullet wipe? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Residual from barrel of gun

 

Explanation:

 

A "bullet wipe" is a gray or black ring around an entrance bullet hole. The ring is formed by bullet lubricant, byproducts of propellant, traces of bullet metal, and residue in the gun barrel from previous use. It is caused due to residue from barrel of the gun.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Blackening: It occurs due to combustion (smoke) produced by burning of gun powder when a firearm is fired.

 

Option C) Gutter fracture of skull: It occurs due to a bullet passing adjacent to the skull

 

Option D) Tattooing: It occurs due to unburnt gun powder particles which gets deposited around the firearm wound.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bullet Wipe (Grease/Dirt Collar)

 

• Black/gray ring around gunshot wound.

• Composition includes bullet lubrication, paraffin, lead, barrel debris, and gun oil.

• Wider side of the ring indicates the direction of fire.

• More noticeable in shots from freshly oiled weapons.

• It  is dark in the center, fading towards the periphery.

• Prominent in clothing, termed as ‘bullet wipe.’

• It serve as proof of an entry wound in forensic analysis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after being exposed to an unidentified toxic substance given to him by a friend. His symptoms include dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation. During the examination, his pulse rate is recorded at 140 beats per minute, and his pupils are observed to be dilated. Which substance is the most likely cause of these symptoms? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Belladona

 

The symptoms described, including dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, increased heart rate, and dilated pupils, are consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. Belladonna, contains tropane alkaloids with anticholinergic effects. Features of belladonna are same as that of Datura, and both belong to Solanaceae family.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Heroin: It is an Opioid (CNS depressant) and have symptoms such as sedation, coma, decreased vitas (respiratory depression, low BP, low Heart rate, low temperature), and miosis. Whereas in the question there is high pulse rate, and dilated pupils.

 

Option B) Morphine: is also an Opioid, and will have similar features as that of heroin.

 

Option C) Malathion: is an organophosphate insecticide. It will have cholinergic symptoms, like Diarrhea, urination excessive, miosis, bradycardia, emesis, lachrymation, and salivation (Mnemonic DUMBELS). These are exactly opposite of those mentioned in question.

 

Educational Objective

 

Atropa Belladona

 

  • Solanaceae family: Datura stramonium, Atropa belladonna (deadly nightshade) and Hyoscyamus Niger (henbane) all belong to same family Solanaceae
  • Anticholinergic alkaloids: All of these plants have similar alkaloids, and all of these alkaloids have anticholinergic properties.
  • Active Principles: Examples of important active principles found in these alkaloids are Atropine, Hyoscine (scopolamine), Hyoscyamine.
  • Sign and symptoms: All of these have similar anticholinergic sign and symptoms. So, Atropa belladonna will also have features same as that of Datura: Dry hot skin, Dilatated pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Decreased Body Secretions, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium
  • Treatment is Physostigmine
  • Atropa Belladona have black berries as shown below:

questions.text: The attachment of Eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Guanyl cap

 

In eukaryotic cells, the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is facilitated by the presence of a 5' cap structure, specifically an N7-methylguanosine (m7G) cap, also known as the guanyl cap. This cap is essential for several functions, including the initiation of translation.

 

Functions of the Guanyl Cap:

 

  1. Initiation of Translation: The 5' cap is recognized by the eukaryotic initiation factors (eIFs), particularly eIF4E, which is a part of the eIF4F complex. This recognition is crucial for the recruitment of the ribosome to the mRNA.
  2. Protection: The cap structure protects the mRNA from degradation by 5' to 3' exonucleases.
  3. Splicing and Export: The cap structure also plays roles in pre-mRNA splicing, polyadenylation, and the export of mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poly A tail: The polyadenylation (poly A tail) at the 3' end of mRNA enhances stability and facilitates the export of mRNA from the nucleus. It also aids in the regulation of translation but does not directly mediate ribosome attachment.

 

Option B. tRNA: Transfer RNA (tRNA) is involved in the translation process by bringing amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis, but it does not mediate the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome.

 

Option D. Shine-Dalgarno Sequence: The Shine-Dalgarno sequence is a ribosomal binding site found in prokaryotic mRNA. It helps in the alignment of the ribosome with the start codon, but it is not present in eukaryotic mRNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The attachment of eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the 5' guanyl cap, which plays a crucial role in the initiation of translation, protection of mRNA, and its processing and export from the nucleus.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1:1000 I.M. - 0.5 ml

 

Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The first step in the management of PPH is the uterine massage
IV methyl ergometrine is routinely administered for all patients
The B-Lynch suture is done if all medical methods fail
Manual removal of the placenta is done if there are retained products

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV methyl ergometrine is routinely administered for all patients


The use of IV methyl ergometrine is not routine for all patients with PPH. If oxytocin, the preferred first-line medication, is unavailable or if bleeding persists despite oxytocin administration, ergometrine or a fixed-dose combination of oxytocin-ergometrine can be offered as a second-line treatment. Routine management prioritizes oxytocin over ergometrine alone or other combinations due to its effectiveness and safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The first step in the management of PPH is the uterine massage: This statement is correct. Uterine massage is indeed the initial step in managing PPH as it stimulates uterine contraction, which helps control bleeding.

 

Option C. The B-Lynch suture is done if all medical methods fail: This is also correct. The B-Lynch suture is a surgical technique used to control hemorrhage when medical management is insufficient. It involves placing vertical brace sutures that compress the uterine walls, thereby reducing bleeding.

 

Option D. Manual removal of the placenta is done if there are retained products: This statement is correct as well. When there are retained placental products, manual removal is necessary. The procedure involves one hand stabilizing the fundus and the other hand sweeping side to side within the uterine cavity until the placenta detaches and can be removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV methyl ergometrine is not routinely used in all patients for PPH management; oxytocin is preferred as the first-line treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient undergoes surgery for a clean-contaminated wound after receiving prophylactic antibiotics. What is the expected rate of surgical site infection in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3%

 

After the administration of prophylactic antibiotics, the anticipated rate of surgical site infection in a patient with a clean contaminated wound is 3%.

 

This is a reasonable estimate for the expected rate of SSI in clean-contaminated surgical wounds. These wounds have a controlled level of contamination, and prophylactic antibiotics are given to reduce the risk of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-2%: This range represents a lower infection rate, which is more commonly associated with surgeries in clean wounds.

 

Option C. 13-20%: This range is much higher and is more typical for surgeries in contaminated or dirty wounds, where the risk of infection is significantly elevated.

 

Option D. 20-30%: This range represents a very high infection rate and is more characteristic of surgeries performed in dirty or heavily contaminated wounds. It would be unusual to expect such a high infection rate in a clean-contaminated surgical case with prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A surgical site infection (SSI) is an infection that occurs at or near a surgical incision or operative site after surgery. SSIs can range from mild to severe and can affect the skin and underlying tissues, including muscles and organs. These infections are a common complication of surgery and can lead to various health problems if not treated promptly.

 

Key characteristics and considerations related to surgical site infections (SSIs) include:

 

  1. Classification:
    • SSIs are classified into three main categories based on the timing of onset:
    • Superficial Incisional SSI: Infection occurs within 30 days after the operation and involves only the skin and subcutaneous tissues at the incision site.
    • Deep Incisional SSI: Infection also occurs within 30 days after the operation but involves deeper tissues, such as muscles and fascia, at the incision site.
    • Organ/Space SSI: Infection can occur within 30 or 90 days after the operation and affects any part of the body other than the incision area. This can include infections within the abdominal or chest cavities.
       
  2. Signs and Symptoms:
    • The symptoms of an SSI may include redness, warmth, swelling, pain, and discharge at or near the surgical site.
    • Systemic symptoms like fever, chills, and malaise can also occur if the infection is severe or has spread.
       
  3. Prevention:
    • Preventive measures are crucial in reducing the risk of SSIs. These measures include:
      • Preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis
      • Proper hand hygiene and sterile techniques during surgery
      • Maintaining a clean surgical environment
      • Adequate skin preparation before incision
      • Proper wound care and postoperative monitoring
         
  4. Treatment:
    • Treatment of an SSI typically involves antibiotics to target the specific bacteria causing the infection.
    • In some cases, additional interventions may be necessary, such as wound drainage, debridement (removal of infected tissue), or, rarely, reoperation.
       
  5. Complications:
    • If left untreated or not managed appropriately, SSIs can lead to more serious complications, such as abscess formation, cellulitis, tissue necrosis, and the spread of infection to other parts of the body.

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3

 

The insight scale is graded from 1 to 5. In this scenario, the patient recognizes that there's something wrong with him mentally, which signifies some level of insight. However, he attributes it to the summer season, an external factor. This corresponds to a score of 3, which is recognition of a mental illness but blaming it on external causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Insight is graded from 1 to 5.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 967.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAP smear


The instrument shown in the image is an Ayre's spatula, which is used in the preparation of a PAP smear. The PAP smear, or Papanicolaou test, is a screening method for detecting precancerous or cancerous changes in the cervical cells.

 

During the procedure, the Ayre's spatula is used to scrape cells from the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix by rotating it around the cervix. The collected cells are then spread onto a glass slide and fixed in a solution of 95% ethyl alcohol and ether. After 30 minutes, the slide is air-dried and stained using the Pap stain or a quick stain method, making the cells visible under a microscope for examination.

 

Prerequisites for PAP smear testing:

 

  • Performed before any vaginal examination.
  • Avoid using lubricants.
  • Should not be conducted during menstruation; ideally done around ovulation.
  • The patient should refrain from intercourse 24 hours before the test.

 

Screening Guidelines for PAP Smear:

 

  • Initiation: Screening should begin at 21 years of age, regardless of the first sexual intercourse.
  • Ages 21-29: PAP test every 3 years.
  • Ages 30-65: Co-testing with PAP and HPV every 5 years or PAP alone every 3 years.
  • Over 65: Screening can be stopped unless there is a history of abnormal PAP, which may require extended screening up to 75 years.
  • HIV+ Women: Annual screening until three consecutive negative results, then every 3 years for life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid): VIA is a cervical screening test where acetic acid is applied to the cervix, causing precancerous areas to turn white. No Ayre's spatula is required for this test.

 

Option B. VILI (Visual Inspection with Lugol’s Iodine): VILI uses Lugol’s iodine for cervical screening. Iodine turns healthy cells brown, while abnormal areas remain unstained. This does not require the use of Ayre's spatula.

 

Option D. Colposcopy: This is a diagnostic procedure where a colposcope (a magnifying device) is used to closely examine the cervix for abnormalities. The Ayre’s spatula is not used in colposcopy.

 

Educational Objective:


Ayre’s spatula is a key tool used in PAP smear tests, which is a primary screening method for cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following interventions is not typically performed in this situation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet transfusion

 

  • Platelet transfusion is not typically performed as an immediate intervention for variceal bleeding. Platelets are responsible for blood clotting, but variceal bleeding is primarily caused by the rupture of dilated blood vessels (varices) in the esophagus or stomach, which is related to portal hypertension.
  • Platelet transfusions are usually considered when a patient with liver cirrhosis has significant thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) or when there is an underlying bleeding disorder. However, they are not the primary treatment for variceal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arrange PRBC (packed red blood cell) transfusion: PRBC transfusion is often necessary to replace lost blood and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. Active variceal bleeding can lead to significant blood loss, and transfusion of red blood cells is a crucial part of resuscitation.

 

Option C. IV Octreotide: IV Octreotide is commonly administered in cases of active variceal bleeding. Octreotide is a medication that helps reduce portal pressure by constricting blood vessels, including those in the varices. This can help control the bleeding until more definitive treatment, such as endoscopy or interventional radiology procedures, can be performed.

 

Option D. Urgent Endoscopy: Urgent endoscopy, typically performed within 12-24 hours, is a critical intervention in the management of variceal bleeding. During endoscopy, a gastroenterologist can identify the source of bleeding and perform interventions such as band ligation or sclerotherapy to stop the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of variceal bleeding:

 

  • Initial resuscitation: The first step in the management of variceal bleeding is to stabilize the patient with aggressive resuscitation measures, including airway management, fluid and blood product resuscitation, and correction of coagulopathy.
  • Endoscopy: Early endoscopy allows for the identification of the bleeding site and the application of endoscopic therapies such as band ligation or sclerotherapy.
  • Pharmacological therapy: Vasopressin and its analogs (such as terlipressin) are commonly used in the management of variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure and reduce the risk of re-bleeding.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended in patients with variceal bleeding to reduce the risk of bacterial infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): In patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic and pharmacological therapy, TIPS may be considered to reduce portal pressure and prevent further bleeding.
  • Surgery: In rare cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to control variceal bleeding, particularly in patients with refractory bleeding or severe liver disease.

questions.text: Which of these characteristics is not linked to superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensorineural hearing loss

 

  • Conductive hearing loss is seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS).
  • “Third window” mechanism due to SCD and enlarged vestibular aqueduct. Schematic representations illustrate inner ear volume velocity with arrows -
    1. Normal anatomy allows volume velocity across the cochlear partition from the oval to the round window (two windows).
    2. Air conducted sound stimulation results in volume velocity from the stapes to be shunted toward the SCD (third window) and away from the cochlea, resulting in increased air-conduction thresholds at low frequencies and/or sound-induced vertigo (Tullio's phenomenon). Positive static pressure in the middle-ear cavity may result in ampullofugal fluid motion exciting the ampulla, resulting in nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    3. Elevated intracranial pressure from Valsalva against closed glottis (e.g., straining, heaving lifting) may result in ampullopetal endolymphatic fluid motion, inhibition of the ampulla, also leading to nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    4. Enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) can also act as a third window, shunting volume velocity away from the cochlear partition and toward the widened vestibular aqueduct.

 

Gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis may also be seen.

 

 

  • High-resolution CT is the gold standard for identification of SSCD
  • Cervical VEMP sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing SSCDS ranges from 80% to 100%
  • Surgery is indicated only if symptoms are severe and disabling. Otherwise managed conservatively with medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaze dependent nystagmus: This can occur in SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of fluid pressure waves through the "third window" created by the dehiscence, affecting the balance organs in the inner ear.

 

Option B. Positive Fistula test: This test, which involves applying pressure to the ear canal, can produce eye movements (nystagmus) or vertigo in cases of SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of pressure to the inner ear.

 

Option D. Positive Tullio's phenomenon: This refers to sound-induced vertigo or nystagmus, which is a hallmark of SSCDS. The phenomenon occurs because sound vibrations lead to abnormal fluid dynamics in the inner ear due to the dehiscence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SSCDS, conductive hearing loss is typical due to the additional pathway for sound and pressure transmission created by the dehiscence, not sensorineural hearing loss, which involves damage to the hair cells in the cochlea or the auditory nerve. Understanding these distinct characteristics helps in accurately diagnosing and managing the condition.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page no. 843-847

choices.text: 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3
5 doses of vaccine with Immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, previously vaccinated against rabies a year ago, was bitten by his vaccinated family pet dog on the toe, resulting in a bleeding wound. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this child? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3

 

  • The patient should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has already received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a previously vaccinated individual bitten by a potentially rabid animal, the appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis is to administer 2 booster doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rectal

 

In the given clinical scenario measuring rectal temperature would be preferred over other methods in a case of suspected hypothermia, especially in a soldier posted in Siachen where the ambient temperature can be extremely low. Rectal temperature is considered the most accurate method for measuring core body temperature because it reflects the temperature of the body's core organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral: Incorrect. Oral temperature measurements can be influenced by ambient temperature and recent oral intake, making them less reliable in extreme conditions.

 

Option C. Infrared tympanic thermometer: Incorrect. While it measures the temperature of the eardrum, which can represent core body temperature, it may not be reliable if not inserted adequately or if there is earwax obstruction.

 

Option D. Axillary: Incorrect. Axillary temperature measurements are less accurate and can be significantly influenced by environmental factors, making them unreliable in cold environments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate measurement of core body temperature in cases of suspected hypothermia, rectal temperature is the preferred method, especially in extreme environmental conditions like those in Siachen.

questions.text: Following a surgical procedure on the lateral aspect of the skull base, the patient experiences postoperative aspiration. However, there is no alteration in the patient's voice. What could be the explanation for this?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior laryngeal nerve injury

 

  • The patient has an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
  • SLN motor supply – cricothyroid muscle → when affected causes change in voice only in high pitch
  • SLN sensory supply – Above level of vocal cords → when affected can cause aspiration.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx so its lesion will not cause aspiration.
  • RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid > when affected will cause change in voice.
  • A high vagal injury will affect both SLN and RLN, hence can also be ruled out.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury: This nerve does not primarily provide sensory or motor innervation to the larynx; its involvement would not typically result in aspiration.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Injury to this nerve would more likely affect the voice since it innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. It would lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option D. High vagal injury: An injury here would affect both the SLN and the recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely causing symptoms in both voice and swallowing mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve, particularly its internal branch, is a plausible explanation for the patient's aspiration post-surgery, especially when there is no accompanying change in voice quality. This suggests that the sensory function above the vocal cords is compromised, increasing the risk of aspiration without necessarily affecting voice modulation handled by the external laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obligate intracellular organism

 

Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e, it is a facultative intracellular organism.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is an obligate human pathogen and is the etiological agent of gonorrhea.

 

Habitat –

 

  • Human is only the natural host.
  • Found in human urogenital tract.
  • Rectal carriage in healthy individuals.
  • Typically seen in pus cells (intracellular)
  • Found intracellularly in polymorphonuclear leukocytes, or a specific category of white blood cells with varying shapes of nuclei.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Catalase and oxidase positive: This is true for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which tests positive for both catalase and oxidase enzymes.

 

Option B. Pili is a virulence factor: Neisseria gonorrhoeae has pili on its surface, which are essential for its virulence, aiding in attachment and colonization.

 

Option D. Shows twitching motility: Neisseria gonorrhoeae exhibits twitching motility, a type of bacterial movement.

 

Educational Objective

 

Morphology of Neisseria Gonorrhea -

 

  • Gram –ve cocci
  • Shape is spherical
  • Coffee bean shaped diplococcic
  • Usually seen in pairs with adjacent sides flattened
  • LPS has highly branched basal oligosaccharide structure
  • Contains fimbriae
  • Possess pili on the surface
  • Motile (Twitching motility)
  • Non-capsulated
  • Non-sporing

 

It is catalase and oxidase positive.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to CTEV.(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral
  2. Forefoot is adducted and supinated
  3. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%
  4. Equinus should be corrected first
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b, c are correct

 

  • CTEV is a congenital foot deformity characterized by several components:

    • Cavus: High arch

    • Adduction: Forefoot turned inward

    • Supination: Sole of the foot turned inward

    • Equinus: Plantarflexion 

    • Varus: Inversion of the heel

 

a. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral: 

 

  • Clubfoot is more common in males than females. The ratio is roughly 2:1. So, more than 50% of cases are in males.

  • Approximately 50% of all clubfoot cases occur in both feet (bilateral).

 

b. Forefoot is adducted and supinated:

 

  • This statement is correct. 

  • As mentioned earlier, forefoot adduction and supination are key components of the clubfoot deformity.

 

c. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%:

 

  • This statement is considered correct. 

  • The Ponseti method, a non-surgical treatment involving serial casting, has very high success rates, often reported around 90% or even higher when followed properly.

 

Other Option:

 

d. Equinus should be corrected first:

 

  • This statement is incorrect. 

  • The Ponseti method typically follows a specific sequence of correction:

    1. Cavus: Addressing the high arch first.

    2. Adduction and Supination: Correcting the inward turning of the forefoot.

    3. Varus: Correcting the inversion of the heel.

    4. Equinus: Addressing the plantarflexion of the foot, often as the final step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In CTEV, male children are more affected than females. 

  • 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement. 

  • There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV. 

  • Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%. 

 

Equinus deformity is corrected at last, following the C-A-V-E sequence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. The biopsy will help in diagnosing the nature of the lesion, which is crucial for further management.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Conization: Conization is an excisional procedure done once biopsy-proven intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step when a visible lesion is present and needs to be assessed.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure done for CIN 1 or 2. It is not suitable for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding without a prior biopsy.

 

Option D. Pap smear: Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. In the presence of a visible mass, a direct biopsy is more appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a symptomatic patient with postcoital bleeding and a visible lesion on the cervix, the next step is a targeted biopsy to diagnose the nature of the lesion.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg662, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg345

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

 

Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii is typically made through serology for specific antibodies rather than Giemsa staining.

 

Giemsa stain is a differential stain which is made up of a combination of reagents (Azure, Methylene blue, and Eosin dye) used widely in cytogenetics and histopathology for the diagnosis of:

 

  • Malaria, spirochetes and other blood parasites
  • Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion bodies
  • Borrelia spp
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Histoplasma spp
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci cysts
  • Bartonella henselae
  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Talaromyces marneffei (formerly called Penicillium marneffei)

 

In parasitology to detect intraerythrocytic (plasmodia, babesiae) and exoerythrocytic (trypanosomes, microfilaria) parasites. It is also used for the detection of intracellular amastigotes of Leishmania species or Trypanosoma cruzi. Giemsa stain is also used for the laboratory diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toxoplasma gondii: Giemsa stain is used for the laboratory diagnosis of toxoplasmosis, which involves the detection of intracellular organisms.

 

Option C. Bartonella henselae: Giemsa stain can be used to identify Bartonella henselae, particularly in blood smears.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Giemsa stain is effective in diagnosing infections caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis by identifying the morulae within white blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxiella burnetii cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. Serology for specific antibodies is the method used for its diagnosis. Giemsa stain is a versatile stain used to diagnose a variety of blood parasites and intracellular pathogen.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT included in Malarial Vector indices?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Slide Positivity Rate

 

Slide Positivity Rate is not a malarial vector index. It is a measure of the prevalence of malaria within a population, typically used to identify the percentage of blood samples that test positive for malaria parasites. This measure is more focused on disease prevalence rather than vector behavior or density.

 

Other Options:

 

Malarial vector indices are specific measures used to evaluate the malaria transmission potential by assessing mosquito vectors' characteristics and behavior. These indices include:

 

Option A. Human Blood Index: Measures the proportion of Anopheles mosquitoes that have fed on human blood, indicating how much they prefer human hosts (anthrophilism).

 

Option B. Biting Density (Man Biting Rate): Reflects the average rate of mosquito bites per person per day, measured through standardized mosquito catches, giving an indication of mosquito exposure.

 

Option D. Inoculation Rate: This is calculated by multiplying the man-biting rate by the sporozoite rate (percentage of mosquitoes carrying the malaria parasite in their salivary glands), providing an estimate of transmission intensity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Slide Positivity Rate is a measure of malaria prevalence in humans and is not a part of malarial vector indices, which focus on assessing vector behavior and transmission potential.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) AAGCTT

 

Restriction endonucleases have specific recognition sites where they cut the DNA. These enzymes recognize specific sequence with palindrome arrangement. These are also called inverted repeat sequences, which means the nucleotide sequence in 5’ to 3’ direction is the same in both strands.

 

AAGCTT is a palindromic sequence and other 3 options are not palindromic sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AAGAAG
•    Complement: 3′-TTCTTC5’ 
•    Not palindromic
•    Not recognized by any common restriction enzyme

 

Option B: GAGAGG
•    Complement: 3′-CTCTCC 5’
•    Not a palindrome
•    Not a restriction site

 

Option D: TACGAG
•    Complement: 3′-ATGCTC 5’
•    Not a palindrome
•    Not recognized by known restriction enzymes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Restriction endonucleases act and cleave at the site of a palindromic sequence, such as:

 

5' --AAGCTT-- 3'

3' --TTCGAA-- 5'

questions.text: A 33-year-old public health officer is assigned to lead a healthcare team aiming to address and manage endemic conditions in a remote village with limited healthcare access. As part of the initiative, there's a proposal to start a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting common health concerns in the area. Which of the following conditions would NOT traditionally be managed through mass drug administration? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A deficiency 

 

  • Mass Drug Administration (MDA) refers to providing a drug to an entire population without considering age and gender.
  • Vitamin A prophylaxis is exclusively administered as per the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) to children up to the age of 5.
  • This prophylactic treatment is not intended as a curative measure but rather as a preventive measure.
  • Treatment with vitamin A is reserved solely for children displaying symptoms of vitamin A deficiency, and such treatment is not widespread throughout the community.
  • As a result, it is not categorized as part of Mass Drug Administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Worm infestation: Managed through MDA using albendazole or mebendazole to treat and prevent worm infestations in the population.

 

Option C. Scabies: Managed through MDA using ivermectin to treat and prevent scabies outbreaks in the community.

 

Option D. Filariasis: Managed through MDA using DEC (diethylcarbamazine) and albendazole to prevent and control filariasis in endemic areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin A deficiency is managed through targeted prophylaxis in children rather than mass drug administration.
  • In contrast, MDA is carried out for conditions like scabies (using ivermectin), worm infestations (using albendazole), and filariasis (using DEC + albendazole).

questions.text: What was ETDRS study related to? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diabetic Macular edema

 

  • Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a clinical trial.
  • The study investigated the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
  • The study demonstrated that focal photocoagulation was beneficial in treating diabetic macular edema.
  • The study recommended that eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal artery occlusion: Not the focus of the ETDRS; this condition involves sudden, painless vision loss due to an occlusion in the central retinal artery.

 

Option C. Primary open angle glaucoma: Not related to the ETDRS, which did not address glaucoma treatments or outcomes.

 

Option D. Non-infectious uveitis: Also unrelated to the ETDRS, as the study was specific to diabetic retinopathy and macular edema, not inflammatory eye diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ETDRS study established the beneficial effects of photocoagulation in treating diabetic macular edema, recommending it as an early treatment option to prevent vision loss in patients with clinically significant macular edema.

choices.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted with dengue hemorrhagic fever. After several days of management, her condition stabilizes, and the medical team considers discharging her. Which of the following is an appropriate criterion to decide the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) After the return of appetite

 

  • The appropriate criteria for discharging a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock include several clinical signs indicating recovery and stability.
  • One crucial criterion is the return of appetite, which signifies a significant clinical improvement and recovery from the acute phase of the illness.

 

SIGNS OF RECOVERY: 

 

  • Stable pulse, blood pressure and breathing rate
  • Normal temperature
  • No evidence of external or internal bleeding
  • Return of appetite
  • No vomiting
  • Good urine output 
  • Stable haematocrit 
  • Convalescent confluent petechiae rash

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol: The absence of fever should be without the use of antipyretics like paracetamol.

 

Option C. Urine output more than 200 ml: This is not a standard criterion; adequate urine output should be considered, but specific volume thresholds are not typically used.

 

Option D. After 24 hours from recovery of shock: Recovery from shock should be sustained, and other criteria like appetite and clinical stability are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRITERIA FOR DISCHARGING PATIENTS: 

 

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of anti-fever therapy
  • Return of appetite
  • Visible clinical improvement 
  • Good urine output 
  • Minimum of three days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion and no ascites
  • Platelet count of more than 50,000/mm

questions.text: Which of these is not a feature of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory rate > 22/ minute and PaCO2 <35mmHg

 

  • This statement does not align with the criteria for SIRS. In SIRS, an elevated respiratory rate (tachypnea) is defined as a respiratory rate greater than 20 breaths per minute or an arterial carbon dioxide partial pressure (PaCO2) less than 32 mmHg. Therefore, the option presented combines an elevated respiratory rate with an abnormally low PaCO2, which is not part of the SIRS criteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) are:

 

  • Fever (body temperature >38°C) or temperature <36°C.
  • Tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute).
  • Tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) < 32 mm Hg).
  • Leukocytosis (white blood cell count >12,000 cells/mm³), leukopenia (white blood cell count <4,000 cells/mm³), or the presence of >10% immature neutrophils (band forms) in the blood.
  • Other signs of systemic inflammation such as elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) or procalcitonin.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin.
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound.
  • Phalanges followed by tibia is the most common site.
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson

 

 

  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound.
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis.
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used.
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection.
  • In general, an increase in Gustillo grade is associated with an increase in infection risk.
  • External Fixation:
    • In external fixation the fixation device is external to skin-external fixator or Ilizarov fixator.
    • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.
    • Open fracture is one of the most common cause for segmental loss of bone.
    • For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.
    • The Rail Fixator is designed for bone transport for reconstructing bone loss following open fracture and sequestrectomy following osteomyelitis. It provides correction through bone transport, compression-distraction and bifocal lengthening. 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. K-nail. Femoral shaft fractures are one of the commonest high energy fractures, and intramedullary nailing is the gold standard management of these fractures. Intramedullary fixation is considered superior to plate fixation because of lower rates of infection, early weight-bearing, and lesser chances of non-union. Unlocked Kuntscher nail (K-nail) should only be used for isthmic femoral shaft fractures. The main drawback of K-nail for use in other types of femoral shaft fracture was lack of rotational stability. Nowadays, interlocking intramedullary nail is used for almost all types of femoral shaft fractures because of better rotational stability.

 

 

Option C. Ilizarov fixator. Ilizarov fixator is an effective treatment modality of open comminuted femur fractures with high union rate, adequate alignment and satisfactory functional outcomes. Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV. For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.

 

 

Option D. Proximal femoral nail. The proximal femoral nail (PFN) is an osteosynthetic implant is used to treat proximal femoral fractures in the trochanter area with a closed intramedullary fixation method. It consists of a funnel-shaped intramedullary nail with slight bending to reflect proximal femoral diaphyseal trochanteric morphology. It has two proximal openings, a larger one distally for a large femoral neck lag screw and a smaller one immediately above for a smaller anti-rotation screw/pin. There are small holes at the distal end of the nail for locking screws.  It can be combined with a wire cerclage with an open reduction for additional stability in complicated subtrochanteric fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixator shown in the image in the question is a Rail Fixator, used to treat open fractures to fill the bone gap.

choices.text: Malformations
Polyhydramnios
Fetal Macrosomia

questions.text: All the followings are seen in Gestational Diabetes Mellitus except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malformations

 

Congenital malformations are not typically seen with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM); they are more associated with pre-existing overt diabetes mellitus. When diabetes is present and uncontrolled in the first trimester, particularly with an HbA1C greater than 10%, there is a higher risk of congenital malformations. The most commonly affected system is cardiac, with Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) being the most common anomaly. A very rare but characteristic anomaly associated with severe diabetes is Mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, characterized by an Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) greater than 25 or a Single Deepest Pocket (SDP) greater than 8, is common in pregnancies complicated by GDM. It results from increased fetal urination due to hyperglycemia.

 

Option C. Fetal Macrosomia: Fetal macrosomia, defined as a birth weight greater than 4 kg, is a common complication of GDM. It is associated with excessive fat deposition, particularly around the shoulders, increasing the risk of shoulder dystocia during delivery.

 

Option D. Neonatal Hypoglycemia: Neonatal hypoglycemia, with blood glucose levels less than 45 mg/dl, is common in infants of mothers with GDM, especially if maternal blood sugar levels were unstable during labor. This occurs because the fetus produces excess insulin in response to maternal hyperglycemia, leading to low blood sugar levels after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital anomalies are not typically seen with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM); they are associated with pre-existing overt diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 2787

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bipolar cautery

 

The given instrument is a Bipolar cautery

 

  • Bipolar cautery, like unipolar cautery, is a form of electrosurgery used for tissue coagulation and hemostasis.
  • Unlike unipolar cautery, bipolar cautery uses two electrodes that are very close together on the surgical instrument. The electrical current flows only between these two closely spaced electrodes, which limits the current's path to a small area of tissue.
  • Bipolar cautery is often preferred in delicate surgical procedures where precise tissue coagulation is required, as it has a more localized effect compared to unipolar cautery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unipolar cautery: 

 

  • Unipolar cautery is a type of electrosurgery that uses a single electrode for cutting or coagulating tissue. It is commonly used for various surgical procedures to cut or coagulate tissues, control bleeding, and achieve hemostasis.

 

 

Option C. The harmonic scalpel:

 

  • The harmonic scalpel is known for its precision and minimal thermal spread, making it suitable for various surgical procedures, including laparoscopic and open surgeries.
  • It allows surgeons to dissect tissues and achieve hemostasis with minimal damage to surrounding structures, based on generation of heat from ultrasonic waves.

 

 

Option D. LigaSure vessel sealing system:

 

  • LigaSure is known for its ability to create secure and consistent vessel seals, reducing the risk of bleeding during surgery.
  • It is a type of advanced bipolar vessel sealing device.
  • It is commonly used in a wide range of surgical specialties, including general surgery, gynecology, and urology, among others.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar cautery is ideal for controlled, precise tissue coagulation in delicate surgeries due to its localized current flow, making it more specific than unipolar cautery.

choices.text: 4 ml Mgso4 (50% w/v) in 16 ml NS
8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS
12 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 8 ml NS

questions.text: The loading dose of MgSo4 in pre-eclampsia is? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS

 

Explanation:

 

The drug of choice for the management of eclampsia is Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4). The most commonly used regimen in India is the Pritchard regimen, which involves an initial loading dose followed by maintenance doses.

 

For the loading dose, the Pritchard regimen recommends:

 

  • Loading dose: 4 grams of MgSO4 as a 20% solution administered intravenously at 1 gram per minute.
  • Additionally, 10 grams of 50% MgSO4 is administered intramuscularly, with 5 grams in each buttock.

 

In this question, option B, "8 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS," correctly refers to the preparation required to administer the initial dose of MgSO4.

 

The preparation details:

 

  • MgSO4 is available in 50% and 20% concentrations.
  • To make a 50% MgSO4 solution into a 20% solution, a 1.5 times dilution is required.
  • For a 50% MgSO4 solution, 1 ml of the solution contains 0.5 grams of MgSO4 (1 ampoule = 2 ml).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loading dose of MgSO4 in pre-eclampsia, as per the Pritchard regimen, is 4 grams of MgSO4 as a 20% solution administered intravenously, often prepared using 8 ml of 50% MgSO4 diluted in 12 ml normal saline.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg273, Williams textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 1840

questions.text: Which of the following causes vasodilation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histamine  

 

The most important mast cell–derived amine is histamine. Histamine causes intense smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, and increased mucus secretion by nasal, bronchial, and gastric glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thromboxane A2: Thromboxane A2 is an activator of platelet aggregation and vasoconstrictor.

 

Option C. Serotonin: Serotonin possesses both vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties.

 

Option D. Leukotrienes C4: Leukotrienes C4 and D4 are the most potent vasoactive and spasmogenic agents known. On a molar basis, they are several thousand times more active than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Leukotriene B4 is highly chemotactic for neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is the primary mediator responsible for causing vasodilation, playing a critical role in the inflammatory response by increasing blood flow and vascular permeability.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV MgSO4

 

The ECG displays characteristics consistent with Torsades de Pointes (Tdp), which is identified by its distinctive polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and a prolonged QT interval. In the setting of pre-eclampsia, magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is not only used for seizure prophylaxis but also effectively treats Torsades de Pointes by stabilizing the cardiac membrane and correcting magnesium deficiency, a common trigger for this arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV calcium: Used for treating hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia-induced cardiac toxicity, not directly effective for Torsades de Pointes.

 

Option B. DC Shock: Indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with Tdp or other life-threatening arrhythmias, which does not apply here as the patient's vitals are stable.

 

Option D. Synchronized cardioversion: Typically used for managing ventricular tachycardia with a pulse or superventricular tachycardia, but not the first-line for Torsades de Pointes in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable pregnant patient displaying Torsades de Pointes, especially in the context of pre-eclampsia, IV magnesium sulfate is the recommended treatment. It helps in both controlling the arrhythmia and providing prophylaxis against eclamptic seizures.

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with pain and swelling in the left side of his scrotum. The surgeon suspects testicular torsion based on the clinical presentation. Which is the most appropriate next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side

 

In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side.

 

  • This is the most appropriate next step in management for suspected testicular torsion. It involves immediate surgical exploration of both the symptomatic (painful) side and the asymptomatic (contralateral) side. Even if only one side appears to be affected, there is a risk of contralateral testicular torsion in future. This occurs as the same anatomical abnormality (high investment of tunica vaginalis/transverse testis are likely to be present on both sides.
  • The surgeon can detorse (untwist) the affected testicle and fixate it to prevent future torsion. Contralateral scrotum is explored and orchidopexy is done to prevent future risk of torsion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of testicular torsion: 

 

  • Timely diagnosis: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and requires prompt diagnosis and management to salvage the testis as the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.
  • Surgery: The definitive management of testicular torsion is surgical exploration with detorsion and fixation of the testis to prevent future torsion. The surgery should be performed within 6 hours of the onset of symptoms to maximize the chances of testicular salvage. At the time of surgical exploration contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed as the same anatomic defect can allow torsion on the contralateral side.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation in an Indian setting? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

CMV is most common infection occurring after transplant. Risk depends on induction agent and seropositivity status. Minimal risk for D-/R-(Donor, recipient negative). Highest risk of reactivation in D-/R+ and patients who received anti-lymphocyte therapy. Prophylaxis is given pre-emptively if periodic CMV-DNA PCR are >500 copies/ml with Valgan/ Foscarnet/Cidofovir. Letermovir has no hepato/nephrotoxicity (Safest)

 

D-/R- patients should receive leucodepleted blood products to minimise transmission of CMV

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EBV infection occurs in 1-2% of post-transplant patients and responds well to acyclovir prophylaxis

 

Option C. VZV reactivation can occur at any point post-transplant

 

Option D. HSV occurs within 1-month post-transplant in the absence of acyclovir prophylaxis Nephrology/infectious diseases/post-transplant

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent and clinically significant viral infection in the post-solid organ transplant setting in India, necessitating targeted prophylaxis and monitoring protocols to mitigate its risks.
