Reference - Critical Care Nephrology /Chapter 95

choices.text: To hold bone fragments with traction
For creating a gap in wound

questions.text: What is the use of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To hold bone fragments with traction.

 

Explanation:

 

BONE HOLDING FORCEPS

 

  • Bone holding forceps are used to manipulate bone fragments in place during surgery.
  • They are typically used in orthopedic procedures, such as the repair of fractures or the realignment of bones.
  • These forceps are designed to grip the bone securely without damaging it, and can be adjusted to apply the appropriate amount of force to hold the bone in the desired position.

 

 

  • They allow for more precise manipulation of the bones during surgery and can help ensure the success of the procedure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To hold bone and plate. For this purpose, a Bone-Plate Holding Forcep is used. They are designed to aid in the reduction of fractures and can help secure a plate in place during installation. Aid in the reduction of fractures such as spiral, transverse, compound, oblique, or butterfly. The clamp can also be used to secure a plate in place while the screw holes are being drilled and screws inserted. The fracture site can also be manipulated with the clamp being used as a lever. It has teeth in the jaws for a better grip and a ratchet locking handle for use on various bone diameters.

 

 

Option C. To cut the bone. For this purpose, a Bone Cutter is used.

 

 

Option D. For creating a gap in wound. Wound Spreader is a specialized device that is used to grasp, retract and manipulate the edges of wounds and incisions, in order to spread the space between them and localize surgical targets with ease.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To hold the bone with traction during the surgical procedure, a Bone Holding Forcep is used.

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue is the xenodiagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xeno-diagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Diagnosis of Chagas disease. Laboratory bred Reduviid bugs (vector/ foreign host) are allowed to feed on the suspected patients (original host). After 4-5 weeks, the feces of the bugs are microscopically examined for amastigote forms of Trypanosoma cruzi (pathogen).
  2. Identification of dengue virus - Intrathoracic inoculation of the mosquitoes (vector) with viruses (pathogen). The virus multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, muscle biopsy bits from suspected patients are fed to laboratory rats (vector) for T. spiralis. The larvae of T. spiralis can be demonstrated in the muscles of the infected lab rats.

 

Advantage of xeno-diagnosis: It is useful in cases where a direct microscopic diagnosis is difficult due to the low count of pathogens in the blood of the host/patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC: This is not a xenodiagnostic method but a laboratory assay to test the enterotoxigenicity of ETEC (Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli).

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: This method is not classified as xenodiagnosis; it is a form of animal inoculation for diagnosing Leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: This is the Elek test for diphtheria toxin production and is not a xenodiagnostic method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to detect the presence of pathogens by allowing the vector to feed on or be injected with the patient's tissue, then examining the vector for the pathogen. Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue is a classic example of this diagnostic method.

questions.text: Which of these labeled structures represents a division of the internal carotid artery? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The structure marked 1 and 4 are the anterior ethmoidal artery and posterior ethmoidal artery, which are branches of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vascular Supply of the Nasal Cavity:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

choices.text: Ewing's sarcoma

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemangioblastoma

 

Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

 

Many childhood tumors have been collectively referred to as small round blue cell tumors due to their primitive histologic appearance.

 

The differential diagnosis of such tumors includes neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, lymphoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor, medulloblastoma and retinoblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a classic example of a small round blue cell tumor. It is a highly malignant tumor that primarily affects bone and soft tissues, particularly in children and young adults.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a small round blue cell tumor of the eye, commonly seen in children. It is characterized by the presence of small, undifferentiated cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is another example of a small round blue cell tumor. It arises from neural crest cells and is most commonly found in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioblastoma is not classified as a small round blue cell tumor, unlike Ewing's sarcoma, retinoblastoma, and neuroblastoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 882

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute respiratory infection

 

Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Kartagener syndrome and C. Situs inversus: Kartagener syndrome also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome is due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of:

 

  • Sinusitis
  • Situs inversus - Major visceral organs are reversed or mirrored from their normal positions
  • Bronchiectasis

 

Infertility is also seen in Kartagener syndrome but it is not a part of its triad.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.

 

NOTE: Kartagener syndrome and cystic fibrosis are two different genetic disorders that can affect fertility in different ways.

 

  • In men with Kartagener syndrome, the cilia in the sperm cells may be abnormal or immotile, which can result in reduced sperm count and motility, leading to male infertility. Women with Kartagener syndrome may have reduced fertility due to impaired ciliary function in the fallopian tubes, which can lead to difficulty in egg transport and fertilization.
  • In the reproductive system, CF can cause thick, sticky mucus to block the vas deferens in men, leading to infertility due to the absence of sperm in the ejaculate. Women with CF may have reduced fertility due to thick cervical mucus that can impede sperm transport or block the fallopian tubes, preventing fertilization.

 

Overall, both Kartagener syndrome and cystic fibrosis can lead to infertility, but the underlying mechanisms and specific impacts on fertility can differ between the two conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliocytophthoria, the degeneration of ciliated cells, is typically seen in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1292

questions.text: Which of the following hormones do not act on the pancreas? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrin

 

Gastrin does not act upon the pancreas. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth.

 

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Secretin is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of acidic chyme. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice, which helps neutralize the acidity of the chyme entering the small intestine.

 

Option C. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of fats and proteins. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete digestive enzymes, including pancreatic amylase, lipase, and proteases, which aid in the digestion of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins.

 

Option D. GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide), also known as gastric inhibitory polypeptide, is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of nutrients, particularly glucose and fat. While its primary role is to stimulate the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells in response to elevated blood glucose levels, it also indirectly influences the pancreas by enhancing the release of pancreatic enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrin does not act on the pancreas. Instead, it stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth, while Secretin, CCK, and GIP have direct or indirect actions on the pancreas.

questions.text: A young marathon runner is participating in a marathon competition. After running for 100 m, he develops pain at the anteromedial aspect of tibia which was mild to start with, but increased on further running. X-ray was normal. The doctor ordered a bone scan. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shin splint

 

STRESS/FATIGUE FRACTURE

 

  • Stress fracture is due to imbalance between load and resistance of bone.
  • It is of 2 types:
    1. Fatigue fracture: Caused by application of abnormal stress on normal bone.
    2. Insufficiency fracture: Caused by normal activity on weak bone.
  • Sites of Stress Fractures:
    1. Lower Extremity:
      • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck. The most common site is metatarsal neck followed by tibia (proximal third in children, middle third in athlete and lower third in elderly).
      • Tibia stress fracture = Shin splints
      • Femoral neck (inferomedial compression side in young and superior tension side in older patients).
      • Rarely fibula lower end (runner’s fracture).
    2. Upper Extremity:
      • Olecranon is most common site of upper limb stress fractures.
    3. Pelvis and Spine:
      • Pars interarticularis of 5th lumbar vertebral (causing spondylolysis) is commonest in spine.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Load related pain often bilateral
    • The hallmark physical finding is tenderness with palpation and stress.
  • Investigation:
    • MRI provides excellent sensitivity and superior specificity compared to bone scan in differentiating from infections or tumors.
    • Bone scan is preferable for bilateral cases due to feasibility, also bilateral cases go in favour of stress fracture as compared to Infection or tumor and also can scan the whole body.
  • Treatment: Symptomatic with cast and cessation of activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lisfranc fracture. A Lisfranc dislocation is a spectrum of injuries involving the tarsometatarsal joints of the foot. The Lisfranc joint is composed of the articulation between the first, second, and third metatarsals bones, and the cuneiform bones. Injury of the joint can range from complete tarsometatarsal displacement with associated fractures and ligamentous tears to partial sprains with no displacement. Lisfranc injuries are uncommon and are often misdiagnosed. Even when recognized and treated promptly, there is still a high risk for chronic disability and complications. There are two main mechanisms of injury: direct, and indirect. A direct mechanism occurs as a crush injury to the joint from motor vehicle collision or industrial accident. An indirect injury is more common and is often associated with sports participation involving a longitudinal force with the foot in plantarflexion with a medial or lateral rotational force. The patient presents with complaint of midfoot pain with weight-bearing, following an acute injury. The pain worsens by forefoot weight bearing, and the patient may describe pain or difficulty with the push-off phases of walking and/or running. There is pain with abduction and eversion of the forefoot. Pain can also commonly be reproduced with passive pronation or supination of the tarsometatarsal joint. Radiographic findings show misalignment of the lateral margin of the first metatarsal base with the lateral edge of the medial cuneiform, misalignment of the medial aspect of the second metatarsal base with the medial edge of the middle cuneiform, and/or small avulsion fragments a one of metatarsal or cuneiform bones. On oblique view, the medial aspect of the cuboid should line up with the medial aspect of the fourth metatarsal base. The dorsal cortex of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform should be aligned on the lateral radiographs. Lisfranc injuries can be managed operatively. Initial treatment includes reduction, splinting, and elevation. After six weeks, if the patient is non-tender and radiographs are negative, then begin weight-bearing and rehabilitation. If there is any tenderness but no displacement, then the patient should be in a boot or cast for at least another four weeks before starting rehabilitation. Any displacement requires surgical fixation.

 

 

Option B. Jones fracture. A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone that involves the 4th-5th metatarsal articulation. The fracture occurs as a result of significant adduction force to the forefoot with the ankle in plantar flexion. On a plain radiograph, Jones fracture is located at the metadiaphyseal junction, approximately 2 cm (1.5-3 cm) from the tip of the 5th metatarsal and has a predominantly horizontal course. It should not extend distally. Jones fractures are particularly prone to non-union due to being in a vascular watershed zone and take longer than two months to heal. Displacement of the fracture can increase with persistent weight-bearing; therefore, immobilization is important, with a non-weight bearing cast for 6-8 weeks. Indications for non-operative management include undisplaced fractures and fractures in patients with limited activity (i.e. recreational athletes). Operative management is indicated in patients that are elite or competitive athletes or when delayed union has occurred. Management includes either intramedullary screw fixation or open reduction and internal fixation. 

 

 

Option D. Nutcracker fracture. A nutcracker fracture refers to a cuboid bone fracture with associated navicular avulsion fracture due to compression between the bases of 4th and 5th metatarsals and calcaneus bone. The injury usually occurs secondary to the traumatic abduction of the forefoot. This results in loss of the normal lateral column support and excess valgus force upon the medial column that commonly causes rupture of tibialis posterior tendon or avulsion fracture of its attachment onto medial aspect of the tarsal navicular bone. Nutcracker fractures are clinically significant because they can interfere with the medchanical alignment of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shint splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus multilocularis

 

E. multilocularis leads to alveolar or multilocular hydatid cyst. The liver is the most commonly affected organ. The multilocular infiltrating lesion appears like a grossly invasive growth, without any fluid or free brood capsule or scolices which can be mistaken for a malignant tumor.

 

Patients present with upper quadrant and epigastric pain. Liver enlargement and obstructive jaundice may also be present. It may also metastasize to the spleen, lungs and brain in 2% cases.

 

The prognosis is very grave and if untreated, 70% cases progress to death.

 

Surgical resection, when possible, is the best method of treatment. Albendazole therapy is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery. In those cases, where surgery is not possible, indefinite treatment with albendazole is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Echinococcus granulosus: Causes cystic echinococcosis or hydatid disease, which typically involves the formation of fluid-filled cysts rather than alveolar-like lesions.

 

Option C. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebic liver abscesses, which are different in appearance and pathology from the lesions caused by Echinococcus multilocularis.

 

Option D. Cysticercus cellulose: The larval stage of Taenia solium, which causes cysticercosis. It can form cysts in various tissues but does not cause alveolar-like lesions in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver, leading to a serious condition known as alveolar echinococcosis. The prognosis is poor without treatment, emphasizing the importance of early detection and appropriate therapy.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation in infectious diseases, a patient with dengue fever develops warning signs like abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, clinical fluid accumulation, and an increase in hematocrit with a decrease in platelet count. Which of the following is the cornerstone of management for a patient showing warning signs of dengue? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Fluids 

 

  • The mainstay treatment for patients with dengue showing warning signs is intravenous (IV) fluid therapy.
  • This approach is crucial to prevent progression to severe dengue, including dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: Only indicated if there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm³) with active bleeding.

 

Option C. Cryoglobulins: Not relevant for dengue management.

 

Option D. FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): Not a primary treatment for dengue with warning signs.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture: (AIIMS Nov 2019)

 

  1. More common in males than females.
  2. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  3. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur.
  4. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct.

 

Explanation:

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR

 

  • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Etiology:
    • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. 
    • The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1.
    • In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb.
  • Treatment:

 

 

  • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture).
  • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail).
  • Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN).
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males.
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucormycosis

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis.

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (Mucor, Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect BDG (in ng/ml) by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes.

 

Level of ≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: The β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose candidiasis as Candida species produce BDG.

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: The assay is also effective for diagnosing aspergillosis since Aspergillus species produce BDG.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis pneumonia: Pneumocystis jirovecii, the causative agent of Pneumocystis pneumonia, produces BDG, making the assay useful for its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay is not effective for diagnosing mucormycosis because the fungi causing mucormycosis (Mucor, Rhizopus) either lack (1-3)-β-D-glucan or produce it at minimal levels. This assay is useful for diagnosing fungal infections like candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis pneumonia which involve fungi that produce significant levels of BDG.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Well controlled asthma

 

Explanation:

 

Well controlled asthma: Asthma, when well controlled, should not significantly increase the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. Uncontrolled or poorly controlled asthma, on the other hand, would be a risk factor due to increased airway hyperreactivity and potential for bronchospasm or other complications in the postoperative period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BMI > 30: Obesity can reduce functional residual capacity and total lung volume, which increases the risk of atelectasis after surgery. Additionally, obese patients often have decreased diaphragmatic movement and may have associated conditions like obstructive sleep apnea, which can contribute to postoperative respiratory issues.

 

Option C. Upper abdominal surgery: Upper abdominal surgeries are associated with a higher risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. The diaphragmatic movement can be impaired after these surgeries, leading to decreased lung expansion and atelectasis, especially in the bases of the lungs. This can increase the chances of postoperative pneumonia and other respiratory issues.

 

Option D. Age > 70 years: Advanced age is a recognized risk factor for postoperative complications, including pulmonary complications. Older patients often have reduced physiological reserve, which means they have less ability to compensate for postoperative stress and changes in lung function. Furthermore, they are more likely to have comorbid conditions that can contribute to respiratory issues.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Well-controlled asthma is not a significant risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications, unlike other conditions such as obesity, upper abdominal surgery, and advanced age.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2591-2594

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube insertion.

 

The procedure depicted in the image is orogastric tube insertion. This involves placing a tube through the mouth (orally) and advancing it down into the stomach. Orogastric tubes are commonly used in pediatric patients for several purposes:

 

  • Enteral rehydration: In children with mild-to-moderate dehydration, an orogastric tube can be used to facilitate enteral rehydration, allowing for fluid administration directly into the stomach.
  • Nutritional support: For children who are severely ill or have significant dehydration, orogastric tubes can also be used for nutritional support by delivering necessary nutrients and medications directly to the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubation: Intubation involves placing a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway and is primarily used in situations where airway protection or mechanical ventilation is required. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. Nasogastric tube insertion: Nasogastric tube insertion is similar to orogastric tube insertion, but the tube is inserted through the nose instead of the mouth. While both procedures aim to reach the stomach, the entry point distinguishes them.

 

Option D. Oropharyngeal airway insertion: Oropharyngeal airways are devices inserted into the mouth to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway, usually during anesthesia or in unconscious patients. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orogastric tube insertion involves placing a tube through the mouth into the stomach and is used for rehydration and nutritional support in pediatric patients, particularly those with dehydration or severe illness.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mineralocorticoids

 

After a trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, the pituitary gland's ability to produce several hormones including ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH can be impaired. The lack of ACTH typically necessitates glucocorticoid replacement, but not mineralocorticoid supplementation. This is because the regulation of mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone) is mainly via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which operates independently of the pituitary gland. Aldosterone secretion is primarily controlled by plasma potassium levels and the RAAS, not ACTH, although ACTH can have a stimulatory effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids: Low dose steroid supplementation is required as they are ACTH dependent.

 

Option C. Thyroid hormones: Necessary due to diminished TSH, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion. LT4 supplementation targeting T4 levels is required.

 

Option D. Estradiol: While gonadotropin supplementation post-pituitary surgery can be complex, replacement might be necessary due to the absence of FSH and LH, affecting estrogen levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Post-hypophysectomy, patients often require supplementation of several hormones, including glucocorticoids and thyroid hormones, due to impaired pituitary function. However, mineralocorticoid supplementation is typically not needed as aldosterone secretion is primarily regulated by the RAAS system, independent of pituitary control.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Chapter 379/

questions.text: If the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimum volume

 

If lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be minimum volume. This is due to the inherent elastic properties of the lung tissue, which tend to make the lungs contract inward when not counteracted by the outward elastic recoil of the chest wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zero: Incorrect. The lung cannot have zero volume due to the presence of air in the alveoli and residual airways even at its minimal state.

 

Option C. Functional residual capacity: Incorrect. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration, which includes the balance between the inward recoil of the lungs and the outward recoil of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume (RV) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. The minimum volume after elastic recoil without the chest wall support would be less than the residual volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the lung undergoes elastic recoil without the chest wall, it would collapse to its minimum volume due to the lung's inherent elastic properties.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. The flowcytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes c & d) is shown below (Boxes a & b are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgM syndrome

 

The given clinical scenario and the flow cytometry is suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome. The flow cytometry shows the following findings:

 

  • B-cell gating (images a and c)
  • Side scatter (images b and d)
  • Decrease in the number of CD40 (image d)

 

In hyper-IgM syndrome the affected patients make IgM antibodies but are deficient in their ability to produce IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies. The ability of helper T cells to deliver activating signals to B cells and macrophages is affected. Many of the functions of CD4+ helper T cells require the engagement of CD40 on B cells, macrophages and dendritic cells by CD40L (also called CD154) expressed on antigen-activated T cells. This interaction triggers Ig class switching and affinity maturation in B cells, and stimulates the microbicidal functions of macrophages.

 

Most of these patients have mutations in the gene encoding CD40 or the enzyme called activation-induced deaminase, a DNA-editing cytosine deaminase that is required for class switching and affinity maturation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bare lymphocytes: This refers to a rare genetic condition where major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are not expressed on the surface of cells, leading to immune deficiency. This condition is unrelated to the findings presented in the question.

 

Option B. Chronic granulocyte deficiency: This refers to Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD), a condition where phagocytes cannot effectively kill certain bacteria and fungi. It does not fit the flow cytometry or clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Option D. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome is a congenital immunodeficiency due to the deletion of chromosome 22q11.2, leading to thymic hypoplasia and T cell deficiency. The clinical and flow cytometry findings in this question do not match those typically seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by a deficiency in class switching due to defective CD40-CD40L interactions, leading to elevated levels of IgM and a lack of other immunoglobulin isotypes.

questions.text: Identify this sign on USG: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

 

Explanation:


The image shows the "Seashore sign" on M-mode ultrasound, which is used primarily to evaluate for lung sliding. The seashore sign is characterized by a sandy or granular pattern in the lower half of the M-mode display, beneath the pleural line. This pattern is caused by the motion of the lung relative to the pleura during breathing. It is a normal finding, indicating that the lung is sliding smoothly against the parietal pleura, which helps rule out conditions like pneumothorax in the area scanned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stratosphere sign: Also known as the "barcode sign," it appears as parallel lines in M-mode and is associated with the absence of lung sliding, often seen in cases of pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Lung point sign: This is seen in lung ultrasound as the point at which the normal seashore sign of lung sliding transitions to the stratosphere sign in cases of pneumothorax. It is specific for pneumothorax but not depicted in this ultrasound image.

 

Option D. Sinusoidal sign: Typically refers to a waveform pattern seen in various types of medical imaging and monitoring, not relevant to the depiction of lung sliding on ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung sliding- seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between pleural layer. Seashore sign- M mode counterpart of lung sliding. Motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes grainy appearance in M-mode, stimulating sand in a seashore.

choices.text: Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder
Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen
Radial artery is the preferred site

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ICU. While taking a blood sample for ABG, which of the following steps would you not do? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

 

Explanation:

 

Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood: Traditionally, to prevent blood from clotting inside the syringe when obtaining an ABG, a small amount of heparin was added to the syringe. However, in contemporary practice, syringes used for ABG are pre-heparinized, which means they already contain a coating of dry heparin that will mix with the blood sample and prevent clotting. Adding additional heparin to such a syringe is unnecessary and can dilute the sample, potentially altering the results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder: This statement is accurate. A patient can have a mixed acid-base disorder where two primary disorders (e.g., metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis) coexist and "cancel" each other out, leading to a seemingly "normal" pH. However, when the components of the arterial blood gas (ABG) like PaCO2 and HCO3- are evaluated, abnormalities can be detected.

 

Option C. If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen: The modified Allen's test is a simple way to evaluate the collateral blood flow to the hand via the ulnar artery. Before taking a sample or placing an arterial line in the radial artery, it's a recommended step to ensure that if the radial artery becomes occluded, the hand will still receive adequate blood flow. If the test is negative (indicative of inadequate collateral flow), it's safer to choose an alternate site for arterial puncture.

 

Option D. Radial artery is the preferred site: The radial artery is commonly chosen for ABG sampling and arterial line placement due to its accessibility, the presence of collateral blood flow (via the ulnar artery), and its relatively superficial location which makes puncture technically easier. Furthermore, complications like hematoma or injury are less problematic at this location when compared to other potential sites, such as the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Adding extra heparin to pre-heparinized ABG syringes is unnecessary and can alter the blood sample.

choices.text: MgSO4
Nifedipine
Ritoridine

questions.text: In preterm labor which drug has a neuro-protective role? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MgSO4

 

Explanation:

 

Neuroprotection in preterm labor:

 

  • The drug given is MgSO4.
  • It reduces the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay.
  • IV MgSO4 should be offered for neuroprotection of the baby to all women between 24+0 and 29+6 weeks who are:
    • In established preterm labor or
    • Having a planned preterm birth within 24 hours.
  • It can be considered for neuroprotection of the baby for women between 30+0 and 33+6 weeks.
  • Dose: 4 g intravenous bolus of magnesium sulfate over 15 minutes, followed by an intravenous infusion of 1 g per hour until the birth or for 24 hours (whichever is sooner).

 

Uses of MgSO4 in Obstetrics:

 

  1. Treatment of Eclampsia (Anti-seizure)
  2. Prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia (to prevent eclampsia)
  3. As a tocolytic in preterm labor
  4. As a neuroprotective drug in preterm labor (especially < 30 weeks)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: A calcium channel blocker used as a tocolytic and antihypertensive but has no role in neuroprotection.

 

Option C. Ritodrine: A beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic but has no neuroprotective role.

 

Option D. Isoxsuprine: Another beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic without neuroprotective properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm labor, MgSO4 is used for neuroprotection, reducing the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay in preterm infants.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 538

questions.text: A study on 100 urban women evaluates potential risk factors for breast cancer using odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI). An OR > 1 with a CI not including 1 suggests a significant association. How many risk factors show a statistically significant association with breast cancer? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3

 

In the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant.

 

A high socioeconomic status does not pose a risk factor. Despite observing a positive correlation, the statistical significance is absent. Any correlation with a 95% confidence interval with the value of 1.0 is deemed as statistically insignificant. A value of 1.0 within this range implies that both factors can coexist without one being the cause of the other.

Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:

 

  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative (protective) association.

 

Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

There are three factors (early menarche, BRCA mutation, obesity), that have statistically significant associations with breast cancer according to the odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals provided.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the neck undergoes radical neck dissection. Which of the following structures is typically spared during this procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digastric muscle

 

Radical neck dissection spares the digastric muscle.

 

  • The digastric muscle is typically spared during a radical neck dissection. This muscle is important for several functions, including swallowing and jaw movement.
  • Preservation of the digastric muscle helps maintain normal swallowing and chewing abilities, which is essential for a patient's quality of life postoperatively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A radical neck dissection is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of lymph nodes level 1 to 5, ipsilateral submandibular gland and tail of parotid, as well as other structures in the neck such as the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve.

 

In modified radical neck dissections, some structures may be spared, such as the internal jugular vein, sternocleidomastoid muscle or the spinal accessory nerve.

questions.text: All are causes for expanding blind spot, except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoplasia of optic disc

 

Expansion of blind spot is not seen in optic disc hypoplasia. Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly that presents due to the underdevelopment of the optic nerve. The optic disc is surrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring known as a "double-ring" sign. This condition does not typically lead to changes in the size of the blind spot, as it primarily affects the development of the optic nerve rather than its function related to the blind spot's expansion.

 

 

  • Physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma caused by the absence of photoreceptors in the region occupied by the optic disc.
  • Lesions affecting the optic disc region can expand the blind spot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. POAG: The rise in IOP in primary open-angle glaucoma causes pressure on the optic nerve head and consequent atrophy leading to expansion of the blindspot.

 

Option C. Papilledema: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling associated with raised intracranial pressure, and the edematous optic disc is swollen beyond its usual margins, causing the blind spot to enlarge.

 

Option D. Medullated nerve fibres: Medullated nerve fibers (optic disc medullation) is a condition of abnormal myelination of the nerve fibers of the retina, where myelination continues beyond lamina cribrosa and spreads into the retina beyond the optic disc. This leads to the expansion of the blind spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic disc hypoplasia, a congenital underdevelopment of the optic nerve, does not typically result in an expanding blind spot, unlike conditions like POAG, papilledema, and the presence of medullated nerve fibers, which can directly affect the structure or function of the area surrounding the optic disc.

choices.text: Minute volume decreases by 50%
Residual volume increases
Total lung capacity increases

questions.text: The correct statement regarding the physiological changes in the respiratory system in pregnancy? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FRC decreases

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Minute volume decreases by 50%: This statement is incorrect. In fact, minute ventilation, which is the total volume of air inspired in a minute, increases by 40% during pregnancy due to an increase in tidal volume.

 

Option B. Residual volume increases: This statement is incorrect. Residual volume, which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximal expiration, decreases by 20-25% during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Total lung capacity increases: This statement is incorrect. Total lung capacity, which is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold, is either unaffected or slightly decreased (by about 5%) during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) decreases by approximately 22% during pregnancy due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm by the enlarging uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg189, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 6

choices.text: Congenital heart defects

questions.text: On finding a congenital heart block in a fetus which of the following conditions would you evaluate for in the mother? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SLE

 

Congenital heart block (CHB) in a fetus is often associated with maternal autoimmune conditions, particularly Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). This condition is related to the presence of maternal antibodies against the SS-A (Ro) or SS-B (La) antigens. These antibodies can cross the placenta and affect the fetal heart, leading to congenital heart block. Therefore, if a congenital heart block is detected in a fetus, it is essential to evaluate the mother for SLE.

 

Neonatal lupus erythematosus, a subtype of lupus erythematosus, is caused by the transplacental passage of these maternal antibodies. The most frequent clinical manifestations in the neonate include congenital heart block and cutaneous lesions. Fetal echocardiography is recommended between 18 and 26 weeks of gestation in pregnancies where these antibodies are present to monitor for congenital heart block.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APLA syndrome: Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) is associated with increased risks of miscarriages, intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), and preterm births. However, it is not specifically associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Option B. Congenital heart defects: Women with certain congenital cardiac defects may have an increased chance of giving birth to children with similar defects, such as Marfan syndrome, aortic stenosis, ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), and coarctation of the aorta. However, these conditions are not directly linked to congenital heart block caused by maternal antibodies.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemias, such as thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and hereditary spherocytosis, are inherited conditions but are not associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital heart block (CHB) in a fetus is associated with maternal antibodies to SS-A (Ro) or SS-B (La), commonly seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 722

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with a yellow question mark ? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner nuclear layer

 

The marked structure in the slide is the inner nuclear layer of the retina

 

  • Present between the outer plexiform layer and the inner plexiform layer.
  • Contains the cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and amacrine cells.
  • Dark stain.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient undergoes parotidectomy surgery to remove a tumor. During the postoperative period, the patient complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great auricular nerve

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (specifically, the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the earlobe and the skin over the parotid gland. Damage to this nerve during parotidectomy surgery can lead to loss of sensation in the earlobe area, which could affect the patient's sensation while shaving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the external ear and the temporal region, which if injured gives rise to gustatory sweating or Frey’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Facial nerve: The facial nerve is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression, not sensation. Damage to the facial nerve during parotidectomy surgery can result in facial weakness or paralysis rather than altered sensation.

 

Option D. Marginal mandibular nerve: The marginal mandibular nerve is a branch of the facial nerve and primarily provides innervation to the lower lip. It is not typically involved in sensation during shaving.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nerves that can be injured in parotidectomy and its significance:

 

A) Auriculotemporal nerve injury – Frey’s syndrome

 

B) Great auricular nerve- loss of sensation in area of shaving

 

C) Facial nerve- facial palsy

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in heart failure?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trimetazidine

 

Trimetazidine is not used in heart failure because it is primarily a metabolic modulator. It partially inhibits the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, which results in shifting the metabolism of heart muscles from fatty acids to glucose. This shift requires less oxygen, making trimetazidine beneficial for patients with angina pectoris. However, it does not have a role in the management of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is used in the management of chronic heart failure. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure but can be beneficial in chronic heart failure when started at a low dose and gradually increased to avoid decompensation. The beta-blockers commonly used in heart failure include carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol.

 

Option C. Sacubitril: Sacubitril is an NEP (neutral endopeptidase) inhibitor, which prevents the breakdown of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP). By inhibiting NEP, sacubitril increases BNP levels, leading to natriuresis and vasodilation, which are beneficial effects in chronic heart failure (CHF). Therefore, sacubitril is used in the treatment of CHF.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a recombinant form of BNP and is administered through the subcutaneous route. It helps to induce natriuresis and vasodilation, thus can be used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Educational objective:

 

Trimetazidine, although beneficial for angina pectoris due to its metabolic modulation properties, is not used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Note - Beta blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure, but they can be used in chronic heart failure. Beta blockers should be started at low dose, dose should be increased gradually to prevent decompensation.

 

Beta blockers used are – Carvedilol, metoprolol and bisoprolol.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 599, 600

choices.text: 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intravenous route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intravenous route

questions.text: A patient was given ampicillin 2 g intravenously. After that, the person developed rash on skin, hypotension and difficulty in breathing. The patient should be managed by? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route

 

Penicillin’s are prone to cause allergic reactions. Features like rash on skin, hypotension, and difficulty in breathing are suggestive of anaphylactic shock.

 

In case of anaphylactic shock the resuscitation council of UK has recommended the following measures:

 

  • Put the patient in reclining position, administer oxygen at high flow rate and perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation if required.
  • Inject adrenaline 0.5 mg (0.5 ml of 1 in 1000 for adult, 0.3 ml for child 6-12 years and 0.15 ml for child upto 6 years) i.m.; repeat every 5-10 min in case patient does not improve or improvement is transient. This is the only life saving measure. Adrenaline should not be injected i.v. (can itself be fatal) unless shock is immediately life threatening. If adrenaline is to be injected i. v., it should be diluted to 1:10,000 and infused slowly with constant monitoring.
  • Administer a H1 antihistaminic (pheniramine 20-40 mg or chlorpheniramine 10-20 mg) i.m./slow i.v. It may have adjuvant value.
  • Intravenous glucocorticoid (hydrocortisone sod. succinate 200 mg) should be added in severe/recurrent cases. It acts slowly but is especially valuable for prolonged reactions and in asthmatics. It may be followed by oral prednisolone for 3 days.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 97

choices.text: To allay anxiety
To decrease secretions
For muscle relaxation

questions.text: A patient was schedule for surgery. Before giving anaesthesia, he was administered glycopyrrolate. What is rationale of giving glycopyrrolate before anaesthesia?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. To decrease secretions

 

  • Preanesthetic medication refers to the use of drugs before anaesthesia to make it safe and less unpleasant.
  • When inhalation anaesthetic agents are given, they inhibit the ciliary function resulting in accumulation of secretions in the respiratory pathway. Therefore anti-cholinergic drugs like atropine or glycopyrrolate are used as pre-anaesthetic medication for their anti-secretory action.
  • Glycopyrrolate is twice as potent and longer acting quaternary anti-muscarinic which does not produce central effects. Anti-secretory action is more marked than atropine and tachycardia is less marked. It acts rapidly when given i.v. and is the preferred anti-muscarinic in anaesthetic practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To allay anxiety: Glycopyrrolate is not used to allay anxiety. Anxiolytics such as benzodiazepines are typically used for this purpose.

 

Option C. As inducing agent: Glycopyrrolate is not an inducing agent. Inducing agents are drugs like propofol or thiopental used to induce anaesthesia.

 

Option D. For muscle relaxation: Glycopyrrolate is not used for muscle relaxation. Muscle relaxants like vecuronium or succinylcholine are used for this purpose during surgical procedures.

 

Educational objective:

 

Glycopyrrolate is administered before anaesthesia to decrease respiratory secretions, making the anaesthetic procedure safer and more efficient by preventing the accumulation of secretions that can interfere with the airway during surgery.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 413,414

questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the treatment of (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chronic gout

 

Pegloticase is a recombinant form of uricase, an enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, a more water-soluble substance that is easily excreted by the kidneys. Humans naturally lack this enzyme, and pegloticase is specifically designed to address the accumulation of uric acid in patients with gout.

 

Pegloticase is particularly indicated for the treatment of chronic gout in patients who have not responded to conventional therapies. Due to its potential immunogenicity, which can lead to infusion reactions including anaphylaxis, pegloticase is reserved for rare cases of refractory symptomatic chronic gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus is a condition of impaired bowel motility. Pegloticase has no role in the treatment of paralytic ileus.

 

Option C. Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. Treatments typically include NSAIDs, DMARDs, and biologics, but not pegloticase.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder treated with NSAIDs, corticosteroids, DMARDs, and biologic agents. Pegloticase is not used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout, particularly in patients who have not responded to other therapies, due to its ability to lower uric acid levels by converting it to allantoin.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 235

choices.text: Muscarinic M2 receptor
Dopamine D2 receptor
Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor

questions.text: G-protein coupled receptor that does not act through opening of potassium channels is(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Angiotensin 1 receptor 

 

G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) can have various mechanisms of action, including the opening of potassium channels or increasing intracellular calcium levels. Opening potassium channels typically results in hyperpolarization and inhibition, whereas increasing calcium levels generally leads to excitation.

 

  • Muscarinic M2 receptor: This receptor is coupled to G-proteins that open potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, particularly in cardiac tissue where it slows the heart rate.
  • Dopamine D2 receptor: This receptor is also coupled to G-proteins that open potassium channels, resulting in hyperpolarization and inhibition. It is involved in regulating neurotransmitter release and motor control.
  • Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor: This receptor acts similarly by opening potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition. It plays a role in mood regulation and other central nervous system functions.

 

Angiotensin 1 receptor: Unlike the others, the Angiotensin 1 receptor does not act through the opening of potassium channels. Instead, it is coupled to G-proteins that activate the phospholipase C pathway, leading to an increase in intracellular calcium levels. This results in vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscarinic M2 receptor: This receptor opens potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, particularly in the heart, where it decreases heart rate.

 

Option B. Dopamine D2 receptor: This receptor also opens potassium channels, resulting in hyperpolarization and inhibition, affecting neurotransmitter release and motor control.

 

Option C. Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor: This receptor acts through the opening of potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, influencing mood and other central nervous system activities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GPCR that acts through opening of K+ channels can result in hyper-polarization, thus leading to inhibition. So, receptor which causes stimulation cannot act through opening of K+ channels.

 

  • Muscarinic M2 receptor, Dopamine D2 receptor and serotonin 5HT1 receptor act through opening of K+ channels.
  • Whereas Angiotensin 1 receptor act by increasing Ca2+.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/56

choices.text: Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis
Washing hands with soap and water is advised
Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick
Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks

questions.text: A nurse got accidental prick from the HIV infected needle. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this nurse? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) involves a series of steps to reduce the risk of HIV infection after potential exposure, such as a needlestick injury.

 

  1. Washing the Wound: Immediately after exposure, the wound should be washed thoroughly with soap and water. This helps to reduce the risk of infection.
  2. Baseline Viral Markers: Blood samples should be taken from the exposed individual to measure baseline viral markers. This provides a reference point to determine if the infection was acquired.
  3. Triple Drug Therapy: PEP should be initiated within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as soon as possible. The recommended regimen includes a combination of three antiretroviral drugs:
    • Tenofovir
    • Lamivudine (or Emtricitabine)
    • A boosted protease inhibitor (such as lopinavir/ritonavir)

 

Zidovudine monotherapy is not recommended. Combination therapy is more effective in preventing seroconversion.

 

  1. Follow-Up Testing: Follow-up viral markers should be measured at 6 weeks post-exposure to check for HIV infection. Additional testing may also be done at 3 months and 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Washing hands with soap and water is advised: This is correct. Washing the wound with soap and water immediately after exposure is a crucial first step.

 

Option C. Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick: This is correct. Establishing baseline viral markers at the time of exposure is essential for monitoring potential seroconversion.

 

Option D. Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks: This is correct. Follow-up testing at 6 weeks is recommended to detect any early seroconversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POST EXPOSURE PROPHYLAXIS

 

  • Treatment should be started within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as early as possible
  • At first the wound is washed with soap and water.
  • Secondly before initiating drug therapy blood samples are taken to measure the baseline viral markers
  • Then, triple drug therapy is given which includes Tenofovir, Lamivudine and a boosted protease inhibitor for 28 days.
  • After 6 weeks again viral markers are measured to check for the infection.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/872

choices.text: 5HT4 agonist
5HT2b agonist
5HT2b antagonist
5HT1a partial agonist

questions.text: Prucalopride is a (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 5HT4 agonist

 

PRUCALOPRIDE

 

  • It is a selective 5-HT4 receptor agonist approved recently for the treatment of chronic constipation, when other laxatives fail to provide adequate relief.
  • It activates pre-junctional 5-HT4 receptors on intrinsic enteric neurons to enhance release of the excitatory transmitter ACh. It, thereby promotes the propulsive contractions in ileum and more prominently in colon.
  • Prucalopride is shown to have negligible affinity for cardiac K+ channels. It is therefore, believed to be free of cardiovascular risk. No Q-T prolongation has been noted during clinical trial. 


Educational objective:

 

Prucalopride is a selective 5-HT4 receptor agonist used for the treatment of chronic constipation, working by enhancing acetylcholine release to promote intestinal motility without significant cardiovascular risks.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/724

choices.text: Both A and R are correct and R is correct explanation of A
Both A and R are correct and R is not correct explanation of A
A is true and R is false
A is false and R is true

questions.text:
Assertion: In a patient admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given.

 

Reason: The combination covers gram positive organisms as well as anaerobes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A is true and R is false

 

  • In patients admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given. Beta lactams covers the gram positive and gram negative organisms whereas azithromycin covers the atypical mycobacteria like mycoplasma and chlamydia.
  • Alternative to this therapy is fluoroquinolones.
  • If a patient is not admitted, then either beta lactams alone or macrolides is prescribed.

 

Educational objective:

 

In hospitalized patients with community-acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is used to cover typical and atypical bacterial pathogens, not anaerobes.

 

Reference: Katzung 13th/878

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy is
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis, including in pregnancy. Bacterial vaginosis is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of the normal bacterial flora.

 

  • Effectiveness: Metronidazole is highly effective against the anaerobic bacteria that are commonly implicated in bacterial vaginosis.
  • Safety: It is considered safe for use during pregnancy, making it the preferred treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for bacterial vaginosis and can be used if metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: Erythromycin is not commonly used for bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly used for infections caused by gram-positive bacteria and atypical pathogens.

 

Option D. Rovamycin: Rovamycin (spiramycin) is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for the treatment of toxoplasmosis in pregnancy. It is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy due to its effectiveness against anaerobic bacteria and its safety profile during pregnancy.

 

Rovamycin i.e. spiramycin (which is a macrolide) is drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/894-896.

choices.text: Peripheral neuropathy is a common adverse effect
It is active against gram positive organisms
It has poor oral bioavailability
Major mode of elimination is renal excretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tedizolid is true? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is active against gram positive organisms

 

Tedizolid is an oxazolidinone-class antibiotic, similar to linezolid, and is primarily used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria.

 

Activity Against Gram-Positive Organisms: Tedizolid is particularly effective against gram-positive pathogens, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA). It works by inhibiting protein synthesis through binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peripheral neuropathy is a common adverse effect: Peripheral neuropathy and lactic acidosis are potential adverse effects of tedizolid, but they are not common.

 

Option C. It has poor oral bioavailability: This is incorrect. Tedizolid has very good oral bioavailability, nearly 90%, making it effective when administered orally.

 

Option D. Major mode of elimination is renal excretion: This is incorrect. Tedizolid is primarily metabolized in the liver, and renal excretion is not the major route of elimination.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tedizolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor that is primarily active against gram-positive organisms, including resistant strains like MRSA and VRSA. It has good oral bioavailability and is primarily metabolized in the liver.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/808

choices.text: Monitoring of lithium therapy
Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy
Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics
Administration of nicotine patches

questions.text: Z track technique is used for (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

 

Z track technique is a technique used for intramuscular injection.


During Z track technique, skin is stretched to one side before injecting the needle so that the point of injection and point of deposition of drug are not in straight line. This decreases the risk of efflux back of drug.

 

Advantages of Z track technique –

 

  • It will not cause any pigmentation
  • Lithium and carbamazepine are oral drugs and monitoring is done by taking blood through intravenous route.
  • Long acting depot antipsychotics are given by intramuscular route via z-track technique.
  • Nicotine patches are applied on the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitoring of lithium therapy: Lithium therapy is monitored through blood tests, not intramuscular injections. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure lithium levels.

 

Option B. Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy: Carbamazepine therapy is also monitored through blood tests. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure carbamazepine levels, and the medication is usually taken orally.

 

Option D. Administration of nicotine patches: Nicotine patches are applied transdermally to the skin. The Z track technique is not relevant for this method of administration.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Z track technique is used for intramuscular injections, particularly for long-acting depot antipsychotics, to ensure proper deposition of the medication and prevent leakage back through the injection path.

questions.text: Which of the following is a schedule X-drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ketamine

 

Schedule X is for the psychotropic drugs i.e. addictive drugs.  

 

Among given options, drug that comes under schedule X is KETAMINE. It is used medically for anesthesia but is also known for its misuse as a recreational drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalidomide: Thalidomide is not classified as a Schedule X drug. It is used for specific medical conditions like multiple myeloma and complications of leprosy, but it is not a psychotropic substance.

 

Option B. Colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic used for treating multi-drug-resistant bacterial infections. It is not classified as a Schedule X drug.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic agent. It is not a Schedule X drug as it does not have psychotropic properties.

 

Educational objective:

 

IMPORTANT DRUG SCHEDULES

 

  • Schedule G: Deals with details of drugs to be labeled 'CAUTION-it is dangerous to take this medicine except under medical supervision'.
  • Schedule H: Deals with drugs and medicine to be sold on prescription-only.
  • Schedule R: Deals with standards for contraceptives.
  • Schedule X: Deals with psychotropic drugs which require special license for manufacturing and sale.

choices.text: Fanconi anemia

questions.text: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fabry's disease

 

Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease.

 

Maltese cross birefringence is caused by a radially birefringent substance such as a lipid droplet.

 

 

Fabry disease is a genetic disorder caused by deficiency of lysosomal alpha-galactosidase A leading to accumulation of metabolic intermediates like glycosphingolipids etc.

 

Urine analysis in Fabry's disease shows oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Friedrich's ataxia: This is a genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and does not involve the formation of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

 

Option B. Felty syndrome: This syndrome is a complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis, characterized by splenomegaly and neutropenia. It does not cause the formation of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

 

Option C. Fanconi anemia: A genetic disorder that primarily affects the bone marrow, leading to aplastic anemia and increased cancer risk, but it is not associated with the presence of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease, indicating the presence of lipid-laden cells.

questions.text: Basophils are activated by? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-5

 

The best answer for basophil differentiation of basophil is IL3 however considering the options given for this particular question in INICET exam the appropriate answer shall be IL-5

 

Interleukin-5 (IL-5) is a cytokine that specifically acts on eosinophils and basophils. It plays a crucial role in their growth, differentiation, activation, and survival. In the case of basophils, IL-5 stimulates their activation, leading to the release of histamine and other mediators that are involved in allergic responses and inflammation.

 

IL-5: Primarily activates eosinophilia but also involved in basophil growth and differentiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. INF-gamma: Interferon-gamma is primarily involved in the activation of macrophages and is a key cytokine in the Th1 immune response, but it does not specifically activate basophils.

 

Option C. TNF-alpha: Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in systemic inflammation and is a major mediator in the acute phase reaction, but it does not specifically activate basophils.

 

Option D. IL-2: Interleukin-2 is crucial for the growth, proliferation, and differentiation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells, but it does not play a significant role in the activation of basophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interleukins are a type of cytokine, which are small proteins produced by immune cells that play a crucial role in regulating the immune response.

 

A brief overview of some of the key interleukins and their functions:

 

  1. Interleukin-1 (IL-1): This interleukin is involved in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses, as well as activation of immune cells such as T cells and B cells.
  2. Interleukin-2 (IL-2): This cytokine is primarily produced by T cells and plays a key role in the activation and proliferation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells. It is also involved in the differentiation of immune cells, such as the development of memory T cells.
  3. Interleukin-4 (IL-4): Plays a key role in the development of Th2 cells, which are involved in the immune response to parasites and allergies. IL-4 also stimulates the production of antibodies by B cells.
  4. Interleukin-5 (IL-5): Primarily activates eosinophils but also involved in basophil growth and differentiation, contributing to their role in allergic responses and inflammation.
  5. Interleukin-6 (IL-6): Plays a key role in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses. It can stimulate the production of acute-phase proteins, such as C-reactive protein, as well as the activation of immune cells like plasma cells.
  6. Interleukin-10 (IL-10): Plays a key role in regulating the immune response and limiting inflammation. It can suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as the activation of immune cells.
  7. Interleukin-12 (IL-12): IL-12 is involved in the activation of T cells and NK cells. It can stimulate the differentiation of Th1 cells, which are involved in the immune response to intracellular pathogens.

 

Ref: Wintrobe’s Clinical hematology, 14th edition

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ferroportin

 

Iron absorption is regulated by hepcidin, a small circulating peptide that is synthesized and released from the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels.

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, as hepcidin levels rise, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed. Thus, when the body is replete with iron, high hepcidin levels inhibit its absorption into the blood.

 

Conversely, with low body stores of iron, hepcidin synthesis falls and this in turn facilitates iron absorption. By inhibiting ferroportin, hepcidin not only reduces iron uptake from enterocytes but also suppresses iron release from macrophages, which are an important source of the iron that is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: Transferrin is a plasma protein that binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues. It is not directly involved in the inhibition of iron transfer by hepcidin.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron within cells, particularly in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. It does not play a direct role in the transfer of iron from enterocytes to the plasma.

 

Option D. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1): DMT1 is responsible for transporting iron across the apical membrane of enterocytes into the cell. It is not the target of hepcidin's inhibitory action.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from enterocytes to the plasma by binding to ferroportin, leading to its internalization and degradation.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 1231

choices.text: Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex infection

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in: (AIIMS Nov 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eczematous dermatitis.

 

Topical steroids are the drug of choice in the treatment of eczematous dermatitis.

 

  • Topical steroids are anti-inflammatory medications that are highly effective in treating eczematous dermatitis, which is characterized by inflammation, redness, and itching of the skin.
  • They work by reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune response in the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermal atrophy: Dermal atrophy is actually a side effect of prolonged or inappropriate use of topical steroids, not a condition that is treated with them. It is thinning of the skin which can lead to transparency, easy bruising, and other skin changes as shown below.

 

 

Option C. Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex infection: Topical steroids are contraindicated in herpes simplex infections because they can exacerbate the condition by suppressing the local immune response, which is necessary to control viral infections.

 

 

Herpes labialis: Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex

 

Option D. Rosacea: Topical steroids may temporarily reduce inflammation associated with rosacea, but their use is generally avoided as they can lead to a worsening of the condition over time, particularly by exacerbating flushing and potentially leading to a condition known as steroid-induced rosacea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical steroids are effective in treating eczematous dermatitis due to their anti-inflammatory properties, but they should not be used for conditions like herpes simplex infections or rosacea, and can cause dermal atrophy if used inappropriately.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology, 9th edition page number 377

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

 

Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect.

 

Berry (Saccular) aneurysms occur when there is collagen deficiency in the internal elastic lamina and breakdown of the tunica media. An outpouching, consisting of only tunica intima and adventitia, protrudes through the defect in the internal elastic lamina and tunica media to produce the aneurismal sac

 

As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually ≤0.5 mm long.

 

The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm.

 

Saccular/ Berry aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm. About 90% of saccular aneurysms are found near major arterial branch points in the anterior circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN: While hypertension (HTN) is a risk factor that can exacerbate the progression of an aneurysm, it is not the primary cause of Berry aneurysm formation. The initial defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Option C. Endothelial layer defect: The endothelial layer is the innermost lining of blood vessels, but defects in this layer alone do not cause Berry aneurysms. The structural weakness in Berry aneurysms is primarily related to the internal elastic lamina and the underlying media.

 

Option D. Adventitia defect: The adventitia is the outermost layer of the blood vessel, but defects in the adventitia alone are not responsible for the formation of Berry aneurysms. The crucial defect is in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Educational Objective:
